description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
The Belgium-Luxembourg hub, which will be launched in October 2021, will gather a network of more than 100 experienced fact-checkers, employees from media organisations (including RFL and Agence France-Presse), disinformation analysts, media literacy organisations.
The aim of the initiative is to detect, analyse and expose emerging harmful disinformation campaigns and to increase media literacy in five languages (Dutch, French, English, German, Luxembourgish).

description:
Belgium, March 23, 2020. 

Article 6 of the Ministerial Order of March 23, 2020 on emergency measures to limit the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus states the following:
- Lessons and other activities have been suspended in kindergartens, primary and secondary schools.
- However, day care is provided.
- Schools can provide new learning materials to students at home.
- Boarding schools, reception homes, and permanent reception homes remain open.
- Colleges and universities only apply distance learning, with the exception of internships for students who can contribute to care.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From May 11th, driving instructors are allowed to resume teaching, and from May 18th, all tests, practical and theoretical, in the AM, A, C, and D categories will be possible again. From May 25th, practical tests for the B, BE, and G categories will be permitted again. However, certain measures will become mandatory such as wearing a face mask in the car during lessons or the practical exams. Centers will also disinfect the car each time. People who are feeling ill are recommended to make another appointment.

description: In Belgium, The National Security Council held a meeting on April 24, 2020, at the Egmont Palace to determine a strategy for exiting the corona crisis. According to their strategy, the resumption of classes will take place very gradually from May 18th. Not all students will immediately return to school. Each community will be responsible for the implementation of this decision in its territory, in consultation with the education sector.

description: The National Security Council of Belgium decided regarding the regulation of schools to restart classes gradually from May 18th. Not all students will go back to school immediately. Kindergartens will remain closed for the time being. Masks for the teaching staff are being distributed. Not all students return at the same time. Each community will be responsible for implementing this decision on its own territory, in consultation with the education sector.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Negative COVID-19 Test,Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The National Security Council of Belgium announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy" on April 24th, 2020 which stated that schools would reopen on May 20th, 2020 as part of Phase 2 of the Exit Strategy. However, Flemish universities will continue to use remote learning until the end of the academic year while Francophone universities are implementing a phased return to work for staff members in line with the four stages of the national Exit strategy.

description: Belgium: Effective 18 May 2020, restrictions at the federal level have been largely reduced but final decisions are taken at the level of the Communities. From the publication of the law amendment (Belgisch Staatsblad) of 30.05.2020: "From May 18, 2020, classes and activities may resume in nursery, primary and secondary education, determined for the groups by the Communities on the basis of the recommendations of the experts and the competent authorities."  (see     At the level of the communities, announcements from 27 May 2020 indicate an incremental reopening of the schools, whereby "Maximum scenario from Friday 5 June:   Full classes can reopen full-time. To this end, the distance rules in the class relax"

description: On July 1, 2020, the Belgian Government announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy effective in the period between July 1, 2020, and August 12, 2020. Preparations for the start of the new school year are already in full swing. The Ministers of Education, in collaboration with the GEES experts, have drawn up a color-coded system that indicates how schools should organize themselves on the basis of the health situation. The Ministers of Education will explain this plan in more detail during a press conference.

description: From October 18th, 2020 until November 19th, 2020, Belgium allows institutions of higher education and social advancement education to continue their lessons and activities in accordance with the "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy from directives of the Communities and the additional measures provided by the federal government. Ministry of Education set conditions for the organization of lessons and schools such as the number of days of attendance at schools, mask-wearing, the presence of third parties, and extracurricular activities.

description:
Belgium, 19 October 2020.

Children at kindergartens and primary schools are allowed to attend school as normal. Secondary schools in the second and third grades will provide distance learning for half of their students; the other half will attend on-site. Secondary school students will be able to return to class full-time, ending distance learning, after April 19. Universities will resume in-person classes as of March 15, and students will be able to attend in person one day a week. Day trips will also be allowed for primary and secondary pupils.

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium - On October 23rd, 2020, Consultative Committee announced the "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy, which raised the coronavirus rules for higher education to alert level 4 until November 19th, 2020. The occupancy rate in higher education is reduced to a maximum of 20% with compulsory face masks, except for practical lessons where this is impossible. The rule does not apply to first-year students.

description:
On October 26, 2020, the Belgian Government announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy effective until November 2, 2020. 
Flemish-speaking region: Safety measures have been tightened in all Flemish-speaking schools. Face masks are made compulsory for pupils older than 12 in the schoolyard unless they can keep a distance. Secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively. In universities, 20 percent of students will be allowed to attend on-site, while the rest must follow classes remotely. Half of the first-year students can attend on-site. However, almost all higher education institutions have switched to digital classes, even though they are not obliged to do so by the Flemish government. French-speaking region: Classes in secondary schools will be done virtually from October 28, 2020,; no pupils will be allowed on site. All university courses are now virtual, including for first-year students. There will no longer be any on-site presence until November 19, 2020. In Flanders, safety measures have been tightened; secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test,Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Wallonia, Belgium, 30 October 2020. 

The Wallonia government announced that schools, nurseries and reception centers for disabled children are temporarily closed due to a measure aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-19. 

During this closure period, the staff member performs his services by teleworking. When their mission cannot be carried out in full by teleworking, the hierarchical superior (rank A4 or A5) should examine the possibilities of adapting the working regime and the work organization in order to reconcile as much as possible the continuity of the service and the needs of the staff members in terms of childcare. 

This decree is effective until November 19 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: For secondary education, pupils in the second and third grades will switch to a maximum of 50% contact education until 1 December. Before 1 December, we will evaluate whether up to 100% contact education will be possible again. For higher education, distance learning will be provided: For first-year students: until 1 December when they can follow contact education again. For older students, at least until the end of the calendar year. Teachers must have online meetings; the same applies for pedagogical study days. No physical team buildings are allowed. This is effective as of November 2, 2020.

description:
Consultative Committee of Belgium decides on outdoor plan: as from 8 March more educational institutions can start reopening with some conditions. 

Priority for young people and education

From 8 March, organised outdoor activities (sports and others) are allowed:  for children (under the age of 13) with a maximum of 10 indoors or 25 outdoors; for young people (under the age of 19) with a maximum of 10 outdoors.
The audience at sports training sessions is limited to one person per child.
From 15 March onwards, additional extracurricular activities of up to 1 day in primary and secondary schools will be allowed again.
From 15 March onwards, vulnerable groups with special educational needs and part-time vocational education canresume classes in person.
From 15 March onwards, students in higher education can attend a maximum of 20% of the classes in person.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Types of people on school premises are limited (e.g. no parents)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 19, 2021, the Belgian Government announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy effective in the period between March 24, 2021, and March 27, 2021:
- The possibility for 2nd-level secondary school pupils to take full-time face-to-face lessons again, initially scheduled for March 29, 2021, has been postponed until the start of the school year following the Easter holidays.  
- Wearing a mask becomes compulsory for all 5th and 6th-year primary pupils, at the latest from Wednesday, March 24, 2021.  
- Full-time face-to-face teaching in secondary education will only be possible after the Easter holidays on April 19, 2021    
- 100% face-to-face teaching must be accompanied by regular tests of teachers and, in a second phase, of pupils.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee is allowing classes to resume April 19th for nursery education, primary education, special needs secondary education, the first stage of secondary education, and the system of ‘learning and working’ in 100% full-time face-to-face education. However, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary education is 50% face-to-face education. For higher education, only 1 day/week can be physically on campus. 
Exams can be taken in person. Indoor day trips will be permitted. Face masks for those in the fifth and sixth years of primary are still required. Interaction between classes is advised to be as limited as possible.
Depending on the covid situation at the time, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary can more to 100% face-to-face education May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Belgium, since 30th of April 2021, schools were open.     In Wallonia/ Brussels, From June 9, certain measures may be relaxed in basic and secondary education.  During the Consultation Committee (CODECO) of May 11, various relaxations and a deconfinement schedule were adopted. To match the standards that will be in effect in the rest of society, some measures will also be adapted in schools from June 9. Here are the main ones:  - The organization of trips for one-day extramural activities can be simplified. Stays with overnight stays will nevertheless remain prohibited.  - The organization of physical education classes and sports activities for primary education will be able to be made more flexible;  - The organization of end-of-year events within establishments will be possible under strict conditions (graduation ceremonies, end-of-year festive activities, parents' meetings, etc.).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with no conditions

description: On May 3, 2021, the Belgian Government announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy effective until May 17, 2021. From May 10, 2021, classes resumed 100% face-to-face for all secondary school students. The 2nd, 3rd, and 4th grades of secondary education will therefore have ended with hybrid education which has been relevant for 18 weeks. In Flanders, all pupils in the second and third grades of secondary education can again follow 100% contact education.

description: In primary and nursery schools, a class (pupils and teachers) must go into quarantine as soon as 25% of the class or four pupils (instead of two) are infected. The quarantine period will also be shortened from seven days to only five days. Additionally, when a high-risk contact has taken place outside the classroom, and a child has to go into quarantine as a result, that child is allowed to leave quarantine to go to school. Partially vaccinated pupils or those who received their last dose more than five months ago must quarantine for seven days following a high-risk contact. However, they may leave quarantine after four days if they take a daily self-test with a negative result until day 7. A PCR test to end quarantine is no longer needed. For unvaccinated pupils, the rules remain the same: they will have to quarantine for ten days. However, they are allowed to leave quarantine after seven days if they take daily self-tests with a negative result until day 10 and strictly apply all preventive measures. The measures will take effect from 10 January and last until the carnival break (Monday 28 February to Sunday 6 March).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: A policy called "COVID-19 Vaccines" has been declared by the Belgian government, which will be operational from April 25, 2021, to May 17, 2021. In Brussels, vaccines are currently available to everyone born in or before 1975, as well as all at-risk patients between the ages of 18 and 64. In Wallonia, vaccinations are available to those aged 65 and older, essential workers, and at-risk groups. People in Belgium can also register on a reserve list to receive vaccines earlier in the case of 'unused' appointments when the original patient fails to show up. Vaccines available include Moderna, Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Johnson & Johnson.

description:
Belgian Vaccination Taskforce stated that people with reduced immunity will be invited for an extra COVID-19 vaccine dose from 13 September 2021. This additional dose will be considered as part of basic vaccination, not a booster.  
This third dose will now be offered to people over the age of 12 who are one of the following:
- Have a congenital immune disorder,
- Are on chronic dialysis,
- Have inflammatory diseases taking immunosuppressive drugs (e.g.
patients with Crohn’s disease, rheumatoid arthritis),
- Patients treated for cancer or who have received treatment for cancer
in the last three years,
- Patients who have undergone stem cell or organ transplants, including
before surgery,
- HIV-positive cases with a CD4 cell count of less than 200 per mm3 of
blood.

description: On 27th November 2021, the Ministers of Health in Belgium at the various levels of government agreed on the implementation of a "COVID-19 Vaccines" policy, which includes the deployment of the booster dose of vaccine for the entire population starting from 3rd December 2021. For this booster dose, there is no priority group. The two criteria taken into account are the age of the person and the type and date of the vaccine already received. In addition, the vaccines used in the booster dose are only the Moderna and Pfizer messenger RNA vaccines, regardless of which vaccine was given in the first dose.

description:
On 15th November 2021, The Belgian Federal Government accepts the ordinance for mandatory vaccination of healthcare workers from 1st April 2022. 
A transitional phase will apply between 1 January and 31 March, during which healthcare workers will have to prove that they have either been vaccinated against Covid-19 or have undergone a PCR test within 72 hours.
From 1 April when the full obligation comes into force for all healthcare staff, those who are not vaccinated will be dismissed.

description:
Belgium, 16 October 2020.

In response to the worrying epidemiological situation in which our country finds itself, stricter rules will apply from Monday 19 October. Based on the COVID-19 barometer, the entire country is at alert level 4, this requires a very high alertness.

Prohibition to enter public spaces between 24.00h and 5.00h, except for essential, non-postponable journeys, such as urgent medical reasons, professional travel and commuting.

The measures will take effect on 19 October and will apply for one month, after which an evaluation will follow.

description:
On March 26, 2020, the Belgian Parliament announces that it will adopt special legislation empowering the government to exercise limited emergency powers for three months from March 27, 2020 until June 27, 2020. The government gains the power to enact laws in the following policy categories, though the laws must be ratified by Parliament within a year after its adoption to remain valid.
- "combatting the spread of COVID19, including but not limited to maintaining public order and upholding public health;"
- "maintaining or increasing the necessary logistical and reception capacity, including but not limited to the security of supply;"
- "supporting (directly or indirectly) the financial and economic sectors, the (not for profit) sectors, individual enterprises and households in order to limit the impact of the pandemic;"
- "protecting the economical continuity, the financial stability, the free market and its consumers;"
- "modifying labour and social security law in order to protect workers' interests and the organisation of enterprises and government, in order to safeguard the economic interest of Belgium as well as the continuity of critical sectors."
- "reorganizing the judicial system."
- "EU measures concerning the COVID19 pandemic."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Since Wednesday 18 March 2020 Belgium has banned non-essential travel abroad until the end of lockdown (5 April). Goods and services can still be transported across the border.

The Schengen external borders closure has been extended until May 15th, 2020. This prohibits entry into Belgium to most non-EEA travellers. UPDATE: The original policy banned all non-essential travel. The new policy bans all travel to and from non EU countries and non-essential travel between Schengen Area nations.

description: 450 Belgian troops’ foreign missions prolonged due to the COVID-19 crisis according to the Belgium government, Mar.22, 2020.The around 450 Belgian military personnel that are currently on missions abroad will have to stay put for another month due to the current COVID-19 crisis. Defence Ministry sources told VRT News that the troops that are currently on international missions in Afghanistan, Lithuania, Niger and on ships in the Atlantic Ocean and were due to return will now probably have to stay where there are until late April.

description:
Belgium’s hospitals won’t be taking in COVID-19 from abroad for the time being from Mar. 27,2022. 
The office of the Federal Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès (Francophone liberal) has told the daily ‘De Tijd’ that for the time being at least Belgian hospital won’t be taking in COVID-19 patients from other European countries. Belgium had received request from the authorities in Italy and The Netherlands for patients from these countries to be brought here for treatment. However, these requests have been turned down.

description:
15th of April: Belgium has banned non-essential travel abroad. Goods and services can still be transported across the border.

The following are considered essential movements:

professional journeys co-parenting schemes providing assistance to a vulnerable person living abroad attending a funeral within the family picking up someone in your family at an airport in one of our neighbouring countries taking care of your animals that are abroad

The following are considered non-essential movements:

tourism leisure shopping refuelling visiting an acquaintance visiting a family member abroad.

This policy is set to last until May 3rd. UPDATE: The original travel ban has been extended to May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The federal immigration office informs on travel restrictions:  "The travel restrictions apply to all non-essential travel to Belgium. Only travel for essential purposes can take place.  The travel restrictions do not apply to:  Nationals of EU Member States and Schengen Member States, for the purposes of returning to their homes;  Third-country nationals who are in possession a residence card (or D-visa) delivered by a Schengen Member State, for the purpose of returning to their homes;"  (see     In addition, there are two additional restrictions for people who do enter Belgium under the above conditions: "The person places himself in home isolation for 14 days; and  The person has a ban on working outdoors during those 14 days (even if he / she is employed in an essential sector), but teleworking is still allowed.  These two conditions always apply to the returnee and apply to all possible transport modes (air, land and sea) used on his / her return."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: In Belgium as of June 15th, Belgium will open its borders for travel to and from the European Union, including the United Kingdom and the four other Schengen countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Iceland and Norway). However, it is up to each country to decide whether to open its borders. To know the situation in the country of destination, it is therefore advisable to consult the website of the FPS Foreign Affairs. The conditions for travel outside of Europe have yet to be defined in light of the evolution of discussions at European level.

description: Any nonessential travel of individuals residing in Belgium and going outside of the country is prohibited from 30 June 2020. Any nonessential travel to Belgium is prohibited, except for travel to and from countries in the European Union, the Schengen Zone and the United Kingdom, as well as countries mentioned on the website of Federal Affairs. Essential travel should be proven with a form. Essential travel includes but is not limited to the following: professional public health workers, cross-border labor in transport, agriculture and other, diplomats or members of International institutions, transit to countries outside of the European Union or Schengen Zone, emergency family reasons, coparenting matters, travel for weddings or funerals, etc.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

Belgium, 21 August 2020.

- All individuals arriving on Belgian territory after a period abroad of more than 48 hours must complete the Passenger Locator Form.

- Anyone returning from an orange zone is recommended to be tested.

description: Belgium s foreign ministry on Wednesday banned travel to Paris amid concerns over a possible resurgence of coronavirus cases in the French capital. Belgians are being advised to avoid visiting Paris unless travellers agree to take a COVID-19 test or undergo a period of self-isolation on their return. The city and its environs     as well as five other French d  partements     were added to a list of  red zones  where travel is being discouraged because of spikes in coronavirus cases. Romania, Denmark, Andorra, Finland, Malta and a large swathe of Spain  including Madrid, Barcelona and the Balearic Islands  have already been designed  red zones  by the Belgian foreign ministry. Three French d  partements were already on the banned list  Bouches-du-Rhone, Guyane and Mayotte. As of Wednesday, Belgium has added Paris, Seine-Saint-Denis, Val-de-Marne, Sarthe, H  rault, and Alpes-Maritimes, according to the foreign ministry website. The move to restrict the movement of Belgian citizens judged to be high risk comes as other countries across Europe issue new travel restrictions amid spikes of COVID-19 cases
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium announces that for people returning from vacation as of 25th September, 2020, going to the red zone will be strongly discouraged and no longer forbidden. Travellers returning from orange zones will no longer be tested. Travellers returning from red zones will have to self-quarantine from the 1st day of their return and will need to be tested on the 5th day. This obligation does not apply if people complete a self-assessment document which, after analysis, authorises them to do so. These instructions do not apply to people who spend less than 48 hours in a red zone, such as cross-border workers.

description:
Belgium has imposed entry controls on non-essential travel outside the European Union and the United Kingdom. Federal Public Service Interior has posted information about Travel to Belgium during the temporary travel restrictions. 
These entry controls do not apply to U.S. citizens who are also nationals of an EU Member State, are an immediate family member of a national of an EU Member State, are in possession of an EU residence card or Schengen D long term visa, are passengers in transit, or are diplomats, international organization employees, or military personnel.

Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No
A test is not required for entry, however, as described by Federal Public Service Foreign Affairs, all persons entering Belgium from outside the European Union, the United Kingdom, or returning from a red zone within the EU, must take a test after arrival and quarantine for seven days.  A map of red zones can be found on the Federal Public Service Foreign Affairs website.

Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes
All persons entering Belgium by air or sea, and those entering by land and who are staying at least 48 hours must fill out a Passenger Locator Form.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: More regions in Europe will become red travel zones for travellers from Belgium this week, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on Wednesday. This means that Belgium will require travellers returning from these zones to be tested and quarantined from Friday 9 October at 4 00 PM. Non-essential travel to red-zone destinations is no longer forbidden, but only    strongly discouraged.    In Portugal, the north and the Algarve will be given a code red, as will the Spanish island of Tenerife, which was coloured orange until now. Some regions in Hungary and Ireland are turning red as well. The Netherlands, too, is almost completely red as Friesland, Drenthe and Overijssel join the list of red zones. Only Zeeland, which borders with Belgium, remains orange. Belgian authorities recommend increased vigilance upon travel there and point out that people travelling from certain parts of Belgium  Antwerp, Brussels and the provinces of Walloon Brabant and Li  ge  will have to quarantine on arrival
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Country: Belgium
Policy Effective Date: starting from October 9 2020
Type of Policy: Prohibition of non-essential travel to Belgium
Target: All non-essential travelers to Belgium

Description:
Belgium has implemented a policy prohibiting non-essential travel to the country. However, there are certain exemptions outlined in the policy:

Travel from European Union countries, the Schengen zone, and the United Kingdom is authorized.
Travel from countries listed on the website of the Federal Public Service Foreign Affairs is also authorized.

For journeys authorized under paragraphs 1 and 2 from countries outside the Schengen zone, travelers are required to complete and present the electronic version of the Passenger Location Form to the carrier before boarding. In case electronic submission is not possible, travelers must complete and sign the paper version of the Passenger Locator Form and provide it to the carrier. Failure to present the Passenger Locator Form may result in refusal of entry in accordance with relevant regulations.

For trips from territories within the Schengen Zone, travelers are required to complete and present the electronic version of the Passenger Location Form before boarding. In situations where electronic submission is not feasible, travelers must complete, sign, and send the paper version of the Passenger Locator Form to the carrier, which will forward it to Saniport promptly. Carriers are obligated to check that all passengers have completed the PLF.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Country: Belgium
Policy Effective Date: From Friday, 9 October at 4:00 PM
Type of Policy: Travel advisory update for regions in Europe
Target: Travelers from Belgium returning from specified regions

Description:
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Belgium has announced that more regions in Europe will be classified as red travel zones for travelers from Belgium. This update will take effect from Friday, 9 October at 4:00 PM. Travelers returning from these red zones will be required to undergo testing and quarantine measures.

It is important to note that non-essential travel to red-zone destinations is no longer forbidden but is now "strongly discouraged."

Specific regions that will be designated as red travel zones include:

Portugal: The north and the Algarve regions will be classified as code red.
Spain: The Spanish island of Tenerife will be reclassified as a red zone.
Hungary and Ireland: Certain regions in Hungary and Ireland are also turning red.
The Netherlands: Friesland, Drenthe, and Overijssel regions in the Netherlands are added to the list of red zones.

Travelers are encouraged to visit the official website, which provides advice for all regions, including the color-coded travel advice to different countries. Clicking on a region will display the conditions applicable when returning to Belgium. As the situation may change rapidly, it is recommended to check for updates on the website before traveling.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Travelling to Belgium from abroad: If a person has Belgian nationality or is a citizen of the EU, the Schengen Area or the UK or resident in Belgium, the EU, the Schengen Area or the UK or a relative of any of the above-mentioned individuals then they may always travel or return to Belgium, regardless of the country of departure.

Yet, they always need to fill in the PLF and, if necessary, also fill in the self-assessment, go into quarantine and get tested.

People returning from red zones, who have been abroad for more than 48 hours and who will stay in Belgium for more than 48 hours, are considered “high-risk contacts”. This means that they must quarantine.

From 21 October to 15 November, only people with symptoms should be tested when they return from a red zone.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)

description:
Country: Belgium
Policy Effective Date: October 28, 2020
Type: External Border restriction
Target: Salaried or self-employed workers living or residing abroad traveling to Belgium for work in specific sectors

Description:
In Belgium, to limit the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus, the Ministerial Decree of October 28, 2020, introduced additional measures for workers traveling from abroad to carry out work in certain sectors.

Testing Requirement: Salaried or self-employed workers who live or reside abroad and are required to travel to Belgium for work in the construction, agricultural, horticultural, and cleaning sectors (as defined in Royal Decree No. 1 of 29 December 1992) or activities in the meat sector (as defined in the royal decree of 27 December 2007) must provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test result. The test should be conducted no earlier than 48 hours before their arrival in Belgium.

Verification by Employers or Users: Employers or users in Belgium who hire workers temporarily in the specified sectors from abroad must verify that the worker can present a negative test result before they commence work there. This verification should take place before the start of the work.

Workers Arriving Independently: If the worker has not traveled with a carrier referred to in Article 21 of the decree, they must present proof of a negative test result obtained within 48 hours before starting their work or activity in Belgium.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium:
Anyone staying for more than two days have to fill out a passenger locator form. Non-essential travel is allowed, except for unvaccinated people who are not EU nationals and don’t live in the EU. Unvaccinated Belgian residents returning from areas deemed as “red zones” due to high levels of infections will have to get a mandatory coronavirus test on days 1 and 7 of their arrival, and place themselves under quarantine until the first test comes back negative. Unvaccinated non-residents coming from red zones will have to do the first test 72 hours before arriving. People who have been fully vaccinated for at least two weeks will not face testing upon their return. There will be no quarantine requirement for arrivals from outside Belgium, as long as the traveler is either fully vaccinated, has recovered from COVID-19 or has had a negative PCR test within 72 hours.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Belgian authorities have announced that a new nationwide lockdown is to go into effect from Monday, November 2, amid an increase in coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases in the country. The lockdown is to last until December 13. 
Belgium's borders will remain open, although the Belgian government strongly discourages travel. Travel is currently permitted with other EU and Schengen Area countries, as well as the UK, Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, and Uruguay, although restrictions are in place for areas with high COVID-19 infection rates. For areas designated as 'Red Zones', arrivals are required to take a COVID-19 test on arrival and self-quarantine for seven days and take another test after five days. If the second test returns positive, the self-quarantine period is extended for a further seven days. Travel from all over countries remains prohibited apart from in a few exceptional circumstances.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Country: Belgium
Policy Effective Date: Currently in effect until 15th January 2021
Type of Policy: Tighter control on travel for persons arriving in Belgium
Target: Persons who have been abroad for more than 48 hours and will stay in Belgium for more than 48 hours

Description:
Belgium has implemented stricter controls on travel for individuals who have been abroad for more than 48 hours and are planning to stay in Belgium for more than 48 hours. These measures are in place until 15th January 2021.

The following aspects will be subject to tighter checks:

Completing the Passenger Locator Form: Travelers falling under the specified criteria must ensure they complete the Passenger Locator Form accurately. This form is required to be filled out prior to their journey.

Compliance with mandatory quarantine: Travelers meeting the conditions mentioned above are required to adhere to the mandatory quarantine regulations set by the authorities upon their arrival in Belgium.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: All passenger travel (by air, by rail and by sea) from the United Kingdom to Belgium is prohibited on Monday, December 21, 2020. This applies both to passengers with Belgium as their final destination as well as to passengers in transit through the country. This emergency measure came into effect at midnight for a period of 24 hours.  This is related to the announcement of the UK of an accelerated spreading of the coronavirus, due to a new variant of the COVID-19 virus.

description: Travel from the UK to Belgium is prohibited, except for the following: travel to Belgium from the United Kingdom of persons having Belgian nationality and persons having their main residence in Belgium; professional travel for health professionals, researchers in the health field and professionals providing care for the elderly; business travel for transport staff; the movement of diplomats, staff of international organizations and people who are invited by international organizations and whose physical presence is necessary for the proper functioning of these organizations, military and law enforcement personnel, personnel civil protection, humanitarian workers, in the exercise of their function; professional travel for journalists; travel for imperative family reasons; transit trips in Belgium in the case of air traffic departing from the United Kingdom, provided that the final destination is outside the European Union.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Red zone arrivals to self-quarantine for up to 7 days; add l 7 days if test positive. In addition, the government has designated certain locations with high COVID-19 activity as  red zones.  Travel with red zone countries is either strongly discouraged or prohibited. Most travelers entering from red zones must take a COVID-19 test on arrival and self-quarantine for up to seven days after which a second test may be taken. If this test returns positive, the self-quarantine period is extended by another seven days. Individuals who stay in a red zone location for less than 48 hours are exempt from this measure. As of Dec. 22, the red zone includes most countries except Australia, Ireland, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, areas of Norway outside Oslo and Innlandet County, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Country: Belgium
Policy Effective Date: starting from 25th December 2020
Type of Policy: Strict rules for foreign travel to Belgium
Target: All travelers entering Belgium from red zones

Description:
Belgium has implemented strict rules for foreign travel to the country in response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The government strongly discourages all travel, and for those who must travel, the rules will be tightened.

For travelers returning from a trip:

Mandatory Quarantine: Anyone staying in a red zone for more than 48 hours will be considered a high-risk contact. Upon returning from such a trip, travelers are subject to a mandatory quarantine of 7 days.

Negative Test Requirement: Travelers returning from a red zone must provide proof of a negative test result. The test must be taken within 48 hours before arriving in Belgium.

Passenger Location Form (PLF): The PLF must be filled out upon arrival in Belgium. 

Changes starting from 25th December onward:

- New PLF System
- Non-Residents from Red Zones: Non-residents traveling to Belgium from a red zone must present a recent negative test result that is less than 48 hours old upon arrival
- Increased Controls: There will be heightened controls to ensure travelers comply with filling in the PLF upon arrival in Belgium. Additionally, stricter measures will be in place to ensure compliance with mandatory quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of 18th January, arrivals by train or bus from all non-EU countries, including Britain must test negative for COVID before entering the country and fill out Passenger Locator Form  PLF , regardless of length of stay. Belgiums government will tighten its rules for passengers arriving by train or bus from all non-EU countries, including Britain, in a bid to halt the spread of contagious new strains of the Coronavirus pandemic, the country's Interior Minister has announced.Persons arriving in Belgium from countries that are considered highly affected by the Coronavirus disease and do not have their main residence in Belgium will be obliged to prove a negative result of the COVID-19 test, before entering the country. In addition to that, all travellers will be obliged to fill out the Passenger Locator Form  PLF  regardless of the length of their stay in Belgium. Bus and train operators will be required to check that all travellers have complied with Belgium's new rules, before boarding.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Non-essential travel abroad remains strongly discouraged in Belgium.

But the cross-roads country of 11 million people is tucked between France, Germany, Luxembourg and the Netherlands with thousands of people crossing the border everyday.

Reports said the government could decide by the end of the week to reduce the maximum length of stay to avoid testing and quarantine from the current 48 hours to 16 hours or shorter.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
The Belgian Consultative Committee decided to ban all non-essential travelers to and from Belgium on January 22, and later on March 2, the Belgian State Council agreed to extend the ban until April 1, 2021, at least.

Following the decision, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo said that the purpose of the abovementioned agreement is to obtain better quarantine measures and test enforcement so that non-essential travel can gradually be removed after April 1.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Non-Belgian travelers may travel to Belgium when:
They reside in the European Union, Schengen Area, or the United Kingdom.
Or they may travel from a country that has been included in the list of the FPS Foreign Affairs.
All other countries are banned from traveling to Belgium. They may only travel from these countries to Belgium for an essential reason. 

Those who travel to Belgium and staying for more than 48 hours need to fill in the Public Health Passenger Locator Form in the 48 hours before their arrival in Belgium.
If you receive a text, then you must quarantine. Get tested on day 7 of quarantine. You will receive a code by text message.
If the traveler didn't receive a message, then they do not have to quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

Non-Belgian travelers may travel to Belgium when:
They reside in the European Union, Schengen Area, or the United Kingdom.
Or they may travel from a country that has been included in the list of the FPS Foreign Affairs.
All other countries are banned from traveling to Belgium. They may only travel from these countries to Belgium for an essential reason. 

Those who travel to Belgium and staying for more than 48 hours need to fill in the Public Health Passenger Locator Form in the 48 hours before their arrival in Belgium.
If you receive a text, then you must quarantine. Get tested on day 7 of quarantine. You will receive a code by text message.
If the traveler didn't receive a message, then they do not have to quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: 2G: Must be (i) either vaccinated or (ii) recovered from COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description:
Non-essential trips in and out of Belgium are prohibited from Wednesday 27 January to Monday 1 March 2021. The travel ban will be monitored for road, air, sea and rail traffic.

Anyone travelling to or from Belgium will be required to carry a sworn statement. A form will be made available by the Minister of the Interior. The sworn statement must be linked to the Passenger Locator Form and supported by the necessary documents.

Only essential travel is allowed during this period, i.e. travel for:

1. Compelling family reasons
2. Humanitarian reasons
3. Study purposes
4. Residents of border areas
5. Professional reasons when performing work-related activities
6. Miscellaneous

In addition to the mandatory negative test result prior to departure, the Consultative Committee would like every non-resident travelling to Belgium to be tested again upon arrival. This can be done with a PCR test or a rapid antigen test. The Consultative Committee has requested that the Interministerial Conference on Public Health, the Testing Task Force and the COVID-19 Commissariat make this mandatory.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium: January 23rd, 2021: The Consultative Committee has restricted recreational/tourist travel. All traveling to and from Belgium for recreational/tourist purposes are prohibited from January 27th to March 1st. The restrictions include air, sea, rail, and road travel. In order to travel in or out of Belgium, people need to have a solemn declaration form, Passenger Location Form, and all other necessary documents (employer testimony...). 
Only essential travel will be allowed. This includes compelling family reasons, humanitarian reasons (health or to assist the vulnerable), study reasons (exchange students, researchers with a host agreement), residents of border regions (they travel to Belgium as part of their daily lives), professional reasons, and miscellaneous (taking care of animals, urgent repairs, legal obligations...)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium will ban non-essential trips in and out of the country from 01-27-2021 to curb the spread of highly contagious coronavirus variants, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo announced on Friday. 

The prohibition will run to March 1 and apply to land, sea and air travel but will not affect cross-border workers or those with overriding health or family reasons.

They instead "strongly discouraged" non-essential intra-EU trips, and warned they might toughen that line in days ahead if the worrying virus variants took hold.

Travel into the EU is already severely restricted.

Already, Belgian citizens and residents returning to the country have to have a Covid-19 test on arrival, self-isolate for a week and then take another test. 

Others arriving also need to show a negative Covid-19 test before taking a flight to Belgium.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium closes borders to non-essential travel. 

Alexander De Croo said only essential journeys will be authorized for Belgian residents and foreigners until March 1.

Traveling for business, studies, family purposes or ceremonies like funerals will still be permitted, but those who decide to leave will have to show a declaration of honor at the border and carry the document with them everywhere.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)

description: As of March 8th, 2021, people arriving on Belgian territory from a territory classified as a red zone and not having its main residence in Belgium, but traveling for the following exempt reasons, are not obliged to show the negative results of a PCR test: workers in the transport sector or providers of transport services; seafarers; the “Border Force Officers” of the United Kingdom; cross-border workers; cross-border pupils traveling to Belgium as part of compulsory education; people traveling to Belgium under cross-border co-parenting.

description: Arrivals must complete Passenger Locator Form within 48 hours before, carry statement of essential travel reason, & negative PCR test within 72 hours of departure.. All permitted arrivals staying in Belgium for more than 48 hours must complete a Passenger Locator Form within the 48 hours before arrival, fill in and carry a sworn statement confirming the essential nature of their travel, and possess a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken within 72 hours before departing for Belgium. Based on answers given in the Passenger Locator Form, health officials may contact travelers and require them to self-isolate for at least seven days. Currently, only travelers from Denmark, Finland, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Norway, and overseas territories of France and Portugal may not be required to self-isolate on arrival.

description:
Travel will continue to be discouraged, even though the country’s ban on non-essential travel will expire on April 19, Belgium’s government has announced.

Strict rules to check persons returning from other countries to Belgium will also be kept in place to halt the disease’s further spread.

persons who have been abroad would be required to fill a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) 48 hours before arriving in Belgium’s territory.

Travellers returning from the red zone are considered high risk, as in this group are listed countries with high infection rates of COVID-19. The latter will be notified by a text message telling them they will be obliged to stay self-isolated and take a COVID-19 test on day one and day 7.

Quarantine rules and tests are mandatory and are checked by police officers; therefore, all persons who do not comply with these requirements risk facing a €250 fine.

description:
External border restrictions in Belgium. Non-essential travel: strict testing and quarantine regime.

The ban on non-essential travel within the European Union ends on April 19. As far as travel outside the Union is concerned, European rules continue to apply. A negative travel advisory remains in effect for all non-essential travel.

Upon their return, travelers must follow a strict regime of mandatory testing and quarantine. The Passenger Location Form will allow the police to identify people who do not get tested on their return. Anyone who does not comply with the screening rules is liable to a corona fine of 250 euros.

description: The Belgian government will ease further domestic COVID-19 restrictions from June 9. Belgium's international travel restrictions remain largely unchanged. Non-essential travel from outside EU and Schengen Area countries, Australia, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand is generally prohibited. All travelers arriving from designated "red-zone" countries must quarantine for at least seven days and take COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests on days one and seven of isolation. Arrivals from "red-zone" areas must also present proof of a negative COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test taken within the 72 hours prior to departure; exceptions are in place for Belgian residents, transport workers, and passengers in transit. Authorities have suspended all passenger travel from India, Brazil, and South Africa due to COVID-19 variant strains active in those countries. All air, ground, and maritime travel - including transit traffic - from these countries is suspended until further notice. Belgian citizens and residents are allowed to return home. Also, limited exceptions are in place for freight transporters, diplomats, and staff of international organizations. Permitted travelers from these three nations, as well as those from the UK and all South American countries, must complete a 10-day quarantine and take PCR tests on the first and seventh days of isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: Schengen Area (with the UK)

description:
The Consultative Committee of Belgium has introduced rules for safe travel within the EU this summer using the European digital corona certificate from  9 June, 2021. The certificate proves vaccination, negative testing, or recovery from corona.

Returning as a resident after staying abroad:

- Green or orange zone: No quarantine or test required (zone status can change during stay).
- Red zone: No quarantine if vaccinated (+2 weeks), negative PCR test (<72 hours), or recovery certificate.
- Very high risk area ("variants of concern"): Mandatory 10-day quarantine with PCR tests on days 1 and 7.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The Belgian government will add several countries to the list of "very high-risk" locations from June 26. From this date, the UK, Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, DRC, eSwatini, Georgia, India, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Pakistan, Paraguay, Peru, South Africa, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Uganda, Uruguay, and Zimbabwe will be classed as very high-risk. Individuals who have visited a very high-risk country in the previous 14 days are prohibited from entering Belgium with minimal exceptions, including Belgian nationals and residents.    Non-essential travel from outside EU and Schengen Area countries, except Australia, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, is generally prohibited.

description:
Belgium has imposed an entry ban for third countries classified as very high-risk zones. Only specific categories of travelers are allowed to enter Belgium:

Belgian nationals and residents
Spouses or partners of Belgian nationals or residents (with an Essential Travel Certificate)
Children of Belgian nationals or residents (with an Essential Travel Certificate)
Transit travelers to other EU/Schengen countries (with nationality or main residence there)
Transit travelers outside EU/Schengen (without leaving the airport)
Travelers with compelling humanitarian reasons (with a Certificate of Travel for Humanitarian Reasons)
Diplomats and international organization staff (with an Essential Travel Certificate)
People indispensable for national security (with an essential travel document)
Transport personnel

Stricter measures apply for authorized travelers before and upon arrival:

They must fill in a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) before arrival.
Anyone over 12 years old must present a negative PCR test conducted less than 72 hours before arrival (for non-residents).
Testing on day 1 (for residents) and day 7 (for residents and non-residents) is required.
10-day quarantine is mandatory for those returning from very high-risk countries (except diplomats and transport staff with essential reasons).
Note: Even fully vaccinated individuals must follow testing and quarantine measures.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Authorities also maintain a list of "very high-risk" locations. Individuals who have visited a very high-risk country in the previous 14 days are prohibited from entering Belgium with minimal exceptions, including Belgian nationals and residents, individuals in transit, transport workers, and urgent humanitarian reasons. Individuals seeking to travel under many of these exceptions must apply for an essential travel certificate by contacting their local diplomatic mission five days before they are due to travel. All permitted travelers from very high-risk countries must present a negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival or an EU Digital COVID Certificate, or equivalent, and self-isolate for 10 days, taking additional tests on days one and seven of the isolation period. As of July 9, Argentina, Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, eSwatini, Lesotho, Mexico, Mozambique, Namibia, Paraguay, Peru, South Africa, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Uruguay, Zambia, and Zimbabwe are considered very high-risk locations.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Migrant workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable),Other population not specifed above

description:
Country: Belgium
As of Saturday, 21st August 2021, the color codes for countries listed in Annex 1 of the EU Council Recommendation on non-essential travel to the EU are as follows:

Green Color Code (Low Risk of Infection):

Albania
Australia
New Zealand
Ukraine
Singapore
South Korea
Japan
Republic of North Macedonia
Serbia
Hongkong Special Administrative Region
Macau Special Administrative Region
Taiwan
Orange Color Code (Moderately Elevated Risk of Infection):

Lebanon
Armenia
Jordan
Qatar
Red Color Code (High Risk of Infection):

United States of America
Israel
Montenegro
Important Information for Travelers from Certain Countries:

Azerbaijan, Kosovo, Lebanon, and North Macedonia, currently on the white list, will have a red color code as of 21st August 2021.
China is not on the white list and has a red color code due to the condition of reciprocity not being met.
All other third countries not mentioned on the white list will be given a red color code.
Please note that the list of color codes is updated every two weeks by the Council of the EU based on ECDC criteria, and travelers should stay updated on the latest color codes and travel restrictions for each country.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: No change in policy. As of Saturday, 28th August 2021, an entry ban applies to third countries classified as very high-risk zones. Individuals who have been on the territory of these very high-risk countries at any time during the past 14 days are forbidden to travel, either directly or indirectly, to Belgian territory. Travel to Belgium is restricted for individuals from these high-risk zones, and they are not allowed to enter the country, except for essential reasons as specified in the previous answer. Other third countries not mentioned in the white list are also given a red color code. Travelers should stay updated on the latest color codes and travel restrictions for each region and country.

description:
Belgium, 1 June 2022, COVID-19: Entry restrictions lifted for certain travelers.

The Belgian government has lifted its COVID-19 entry restrictions on nonessential travel from outside the EU.

- As of May 23, individuals who are traveling from outside the EU for nonessential purposes will be allowed to enter Belgium.
- Travelers from outside the EU will no longer be required to:
-- Test for COVID-19 on the first and seventh day of arrival.
-- Undergo a 10-day quarantine.
-- Complete the Passenger Locator Form.
-- Have a valid COVID-19 vaccination or recovery certificate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK)

description:
May 4, 2020: Belgium will introduce a new contact tracing strategy as a part of the "Health Monitoring" policy, from May 11 onward. The strategy looks as follows:

When a patient is tested, the doctor performing the test will ask the patient to record their contacts over the last few days.

From the middle of this week, patients infected with Covid-19 will be contacted by a call centre to ask who they have been in close contact with over the past few days. The form they filled out may be helpful during this call. People who have recently been in close contact with an infected person will also be called by the call centre. Their state of health will be assessed and, on that basis, they will be asked to take the necessary measures.

The infected patients’ general practitioner will already ask them whether they have been in close contact with certain people, such as people living in the same household. In this case, the general practitioner can issue a quarantine certificate for these people, even if the individuals concerned do not (yet) show symptoms and are fit for work. Individuals who have been issued with such a quarantine certificate must comply with the isolation measures. They can, however, work from home.

Under certain, strictly defined conditions this quarantine certificate may also be issued by the call centre under the responsibility of a hygiene inspector.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgian authorities announced the easing of COVID-19 restrictions on September 23. Self-isolate has been reduced from 14 days to seven. description:
30 September: After having been rolled out to more than 10,000 users, the Coronalert application is now accessible to the entire Belgian population. This application is one of the tools used in the fight against Covid-19. The application works with green and red screens. A green screen means that the user is at low risk and that he/she had no high-risk contact. In case of a high-risk contact, the application will display a red screen. Two scenarios are possible. If you have symptoms of coronavirus, the application will advise you to contact your doctor. If you don’t have any symptoms, the application will suggest you to contact the contact centre which will provide more information about being tested.

Anyone who takes the test can receive the result via the app and automatically inform his/her high-risk contacts in case of a positive result
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: To facilitate the distribution of face masks, Belgian governments have listed the following priority target groups: hospitals, ambulances, triage centers, health workers, laboratory personnel and suspected / confirmed covid-19 cases in residential care centers. The policy applies to the whole of Belgium.This list was published on March 25th. It was then still unclear whether these groups would be the only groups to receive face masks, or the first groups to receive masks.

description:
Belgium, March 25, 2020: In accordance with the new "Health Resources" policy in effect until April 4, 2020, several waves of mask delivery and distribution have already been organized in Belgium since the beginning of the crisis due to the spread of coronavirus.

By March 24, 2020, 16,500,000 surgical masks have already arrived in Belgium and have been distributed or are in the process of distribution, as well as 544,000 FFP2 masks. New deliveries are scheduled in the coming two weeks, including a daily arrival of FFP2 masks. In total, 30,500,000 surgical masks have been ordered, together with 5,359,000 FFP2 masks.

Mask orders are placed by the Federal State and the federated entities (Regions) as well. Their distribution is coordinated by the Province Governors.

For the effective distribution of masks, the authorities have identified the following target groups as priorities: hospitals, ambulances, sorting centers, health professionals in general, laboratory staff, and suspicious/confirmed cases in residential communities.

A special Task Force has been set up to monitor the supplies and renew the orders as soon as it appears necessary.

The authorities have also built up a strategic stock. Currently, this stock is 422,060 masks, of which 286,510 are surgical masks and 135,550 FFP2 masks.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium, 31 March: All our hospitals have also been divided into two areas to keep the patients with a COVID-19 infection away from the others. Both the general hospital and the COVID-19 hospital have an emergency department, an intensive care department and naturally the normal hospital departments as well, so that all patients can be well cared-for. Doctors, nurses, healthcare specialists and a great many other staff are ready to give you the best possible care in all these departments.If you have serious symptoms caused by the Coronavirus, you will be helped at the hospital’s specially equipped Covid department. Owing to the huge effort made by our hospitals, there are 1,765 beds available in intensive care with all the equipment needed, such as ventilators for the most vulnerable patients. If we cannot get the virus under control together quickly, then further new beds can be added. There are 7,641 beds ready for people who do not need intensive treatment or ventilation, especially for the treatment of patients with a COVID-19 infection. Our ambulances are also prepared for transporting patients with an infection to hospital safely.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: The FAMHP has put in new measures to avoid medication shortages. Strategic stocks of hydroxychloroquine, Kaletra, and Rocuronium (curare) have been put in place in hospitals and Sufentanil
Atracurium besilate, and Rocuronium bromide will be distributed strategically to hospitals. 
There is also a distribution quota of some medicines like Esmeron, Nimbex, Morphine Sterop, Rapifen, Dipidolor Sufenta, Fentanyl and Hypnomidate to hospitals based on intensive care beds for Covid-19 patients. 
Derogation of the importation of foreign batches of clarithromycin, noradrenaline, sufentanil, alfentanil and hypnomidate has been granted. 
The FAMHP has asked hospitals to use medicines rationally and not stockpile them unnecessarily.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium allows the delivery of an allowance to centres of public social action in order to fund food security activities in April 1st,2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium: to avoid stock shortages, the FAMHP (Federal Agency for Medicines and Health Products), on April 1, 2020, declared a ban on the exportation of certain raw materials and medicines outside of the European Economic Area (EEA) until May 1, 2020. All exports within EEA must be verified beforehand by FAMHP. A mandatory quota on wholesalers is limiting the sale quantities of the drugs and raw materials to the quantities corresponding to last year's sales for the same period, with an increase of sales by a maximum of 50%. Hospitals, hospital pharmacies, and pharmacies must report excesses of 50% of stockpiles of drugs above one month's sales volume to the FAMHP for the agency to redistribute. There are 49 drugs involved in this ban, quota, and stockpile restriction, as well as 53 raw materials.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: In order to avoid stock shortages the FAMHP has declared a ban on the exportation of certain raw materials and medicines outside of the European Economic Area (EEA). All exports within EEA must be verified beforehand by FAMHP. 
A mandatory quota on wholesalers is limiting the sale quantities of the drugs and raw materials to the quantities corresponding to last year's sales for the same period with an increase of sales by a maximum of 50%. 
Hospitals, hospital pharmacies, and pharmacies must report excesses of 50% of stockpiles of drugs above one month's sales volume to the FAMHP in order for the agency to redistribute. 
There are 49 drugs involved in this ban, quota, and stockpile restriction as well as 53 raw materials. UPDATE: UPDATE: Belgium: April 8th, 2020: the export ban outside of the EEA has been lifted. In its place, a notification or exportation, with a possibility of opposition, is required. The list of drugs has also been updated for clarification
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

A mandatory quota on wholesalers is limiting the sale quantities of the drugs and raw materials to the quantities corresponding to last year's sales for the same period with an increase of sales by a maximum of 50%.

Measures will be in place until May 1st. UPDATE: UPDATE: Belgium: April 28th, 2020: These measures were mean to be in place until May 1st, they now have been extended to June 1st.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium, 10 April: Minister Philippe De Backer’s Task Force has significantly increased testing capacity in our country. As a first priority, 20,000 tests have been made available for residential care centres and retirement and nursing homes.Last weekend, the distribution of the first batch of test kits started along with all the necessary material. A total of 11,000 kits are being distributed in Flanders, 7,000 in Wallonia and 2,000 in Brussels. Each of the three regions drew up a list of institutions that should receive test kits as a matter of priority.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
Belgium publishes "Exit strategy" measures extended until May 03. 

The federal government and the federated constituent entities are working together to provide every citizen with at least one standard-compliant cloth face mask that completely covers the mouth and nose free of charge. Various initiatives are already underway. The authorities also want citizens to be given two "filters" each, which they can put in masks that have already been purchased or made. Surgical face masks and FFP2 masks are reserved for professionals in the health sector, in retirement homes and in community facilities and security services.

In the world of work, the employer - including in the public sector - must provide workers with means of protection when necessary.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Belgium: The FAMHP has put in place a new version of the Alternative Test Protocol for surgical and comfort masks. Due to the shortage of masks and several masks not having the certificates, declarations, or test reports to demonstrate European or international requirements. This new test meets Bureau for Standardisation (NBN) directives for comfort masks. This test will make it that more masks meet standards and can be used legally.
The test states that when masks reach a Bacterial Filtration Efficiency of 70% they can be released as comfort masks. The tests are performed in authorised laboratories and results will be made public.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, 4 June 2020. Royal Decree #22 on the creation of a Indemnisation Fund for volunteers victims of COVID-19.

It is essential to take measures aimed at ensuring the proper functioning of voluntary organizations that intervene in particular to guarantee the protection of the population and measures aimed at supporting the voluntary commitment of these people for the benefit of the population as a whole. 

a) The death of the volunteer is the subject of compensation in favor of a limited number of beneficiaries dependent on him. Health care is covered by the compulsory health care insurance. If the volunteer infected with the COVID-19 is sick without dying, carries out a professional activity and is unable to work, the loss of income will be covered by the guaranteed salary or social security due to his/her subjection as an employee, civil servant, self-employed. 

b) The compensation is of a lump-sum nature by the payment of a capital the amount of which depends on the link that existed between the deceased volunteer and the beneficiary. The amounts are set at the same level as that of victims of asbestos caused by asbestos who have died: for the partner (18,651 euros), the ex-partner who receives alimony (9,325.50 euros) and children still receiving family allowances (15,542.50 euros).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Belgium, Wallonia, 23 June 2020.

The government of Wallonia plans to reduce the number of "contact tracers" to follow up on the contacts of people infected with the coronavirus.

Aviq (Agency for a Quality Life) announced that on July 1, the resources will be adapted to reality again, and only 90 people will remain in this mission. On August 1, there will be only 40 of them, "if the level of infection corresponds to the current indicators".
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, October 19, 2020.

Urgent operations and life-saving treatments, such as chemotherapy and dialysis, continue. Hospitals are allowed to gradually allow nonurgent operations again, which were postponed to free up hospital capacity, but are required to keep half of their ICU beds for COVID patients by March 8. In care homes, two visitors are allowed and must be the same for a period of 15 days, after which they can be replaced.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from Oct. 26,2020, COVID care capacity in the country’s hospitals increased.With the number of hospital admissions of patients with COVID-19 now having reached almost 500 per day, the Federal Health Minister Frank Vandenbroucke (Flemish socialist) has announced a number of measures to upscale COVID care capacity in Belgium’s hospitals. Speaking at the Consultative Committee press conference on Friday morning, Mr Vandenbroucke said that the high number of admissions of patients with COVID-19 means that the equivalent of the capacity of one entire hospital per day is now being taken up by new COVID-19 patients.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
