description:
Belgium buys 10,000 courses of Pfizer coronavirus drug on Jan 3,2022.
Belgium has placed an order for 10,000 courses of the pharmaceutical company Pfizer’s anti-viral drug Paxlovid. Anti-viral drugs prevent coronavirus cells from multiplying and as such can aid the treatment of those that have become infected with the virus. The order for 10,000 courses of Paxlovid has come after the Covid Therapeutics Task Force issued a positive advice on the use of the drug for the treatment of COVID-19 patients in Belgium.

description:
On March 30, 2020, Belgium is aiming to significantly boost its capacity to test patients for the new coronavirus (Covid-19) to 10,000 per day, up from the current 2,000.
An initiative to increase the number of daily coronavirus tests was launched last week by Digital Minister Philippe de Backer and Health Minister Maggie De Block.
“We follow a strategy to progressively increase the number of tests from 2,000 to 10,000 per day,” De Backer wrote in an online statement.
Currently, the official guidelines on testing dictate that only medical staff and hospitalised patients with apparent symptoms should be tested.

description:
From April 10 to April 25, 2020, the "Health Testing" policy put in place by Minister Philippe De Backer's Task Force significantly increased  Belgium's testing capability. As a first priority, 20,000 tests have been made available for residential care centres and retirement and nursing homes.
Last weekend, the distribution of the first batch of test kits started along with all the necessary material. A total of 11,000 kits are being distributed in Flanders, 7,000 in Wallonia and 2,000 in Brussels. Each of the three regions drew up a list of institutions that should receive test kits as a matter of priority.
After delivery, the residential care centres and retirement and nursing homes can take a sample from their residents and their staff. These samples are then collected and transferred to the laboratory so that the results for each institution are available as quickly as possible. Each institution will therefore clearly be able to see how many COVID-19 infections there are and the necessary measures can be taken quickly.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 4, 2020, Belgium implemented a "Health Testing" policy, which involves expanding the testing criteria to all symptomatic patients. People who have been in contact with infected patients can also be tested according to established guidelines. Any individual doctor may carry out the tests on his patients, provided he has the sampling equipment required as well as the necessary protective equipment.  Alternatively, he can also refer his patients to a triage centre set up by a circle of general practitioners, which will have testing facilities in place and organised itself for this purpose. 
The patient’s general practitioner can consult the results of the tests carried out on a results server, even if the sample was taken by someone else, such as a triage centre or the coordinating doctor of a nursing home. During this coming week, it will also be ensured that the attending physician who manages the patient’s overall medical record receives automatic notification of the test result in their secure e-mail inbox and can therefore contact the patient immediately, even if they have not performed the sample collection and prescribed the test themselves.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Symptomatic people,Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
May 4th, 2020: Belgium changes its "Health Testing" strategy. Testing will (again) be scaled up from 11 May 2020 onward. The strategy looks as follows:

"The test criteria have been expanded to test all symptomatic patients. People who have been in contact with infected patients can also be tested according to established guidelines. 

Any individual doctor may carry out the tests on his patients, provided he has the sampling equipment required as well as the necessary protective equipment. He will then work in close collaboration with the laboratory which usually processes his analysis requests and will obtain his supplies from this same laboratory. Alternatively, he can also refer his patients to a triage centre set up by a circle of general practitioners, which will have testing facilities in place and organised itself for this purpose. 

Triage centres that have the analyses carried out by the federal testing platform will be supplied with protective equipment and sampling devices by the federal platform. This platform will also ensure the samples are collected and dispatched to analysis laboratories."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium implemented a "Health Testing" policy on November 11th, 2020, which comprised of the following provisions: For those travelling within or out of the country will receive a text message through contact tracing with an activation code to be tested. Testing will occur on the 7th day of quarantine, however. If the test is late, a person must continue to be in quarantine until they receive their results. If it returns positive, then the person must quarantine for an additional 7 days and take the test again on the last day. 
People who suspect high-risk contact, but have not received a text, cannot be tested. 
Results will be uploaded to the covid-test portal or the coronalert application. Doctors are no longer necessary as go-betweens.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium's quarantine rules are set to change again from Monday as the government begins allowing asymptomatic people to be tested for the new coronavirus again.

From 23 November, Covid-19 tests will resume for people who do not have any symptoms but have had a high-risk contact or returned from a red-travel zone, following their suspension to ease pressure on labs.

Asymptomatic people will have to get tested seven days after they were in contact with an infected person and quarantine at least until they receive their test results back.

description:
The free PCR tests prior to travel are intended for people in Belgium from 26 June 2021 who have not yet had the opportunity to be (fully) vaccinated.
Specifically, you must meet the following conditions:
You are 6 years of age or older
You have your main residence in Belgium
You have not yet received an invitation for vaccination
OR you were invited for vaccination once, less than 35 days ago, and have not yet received your second invitation
OR you got your first dose less than 35 days after receiving the first invitation, but you have not yet been fully vaccinated.

description:
Belgium: Testing and quarantine rules
The Consultative Committee has taken note of the decision of the Health Ministers who, on the basis of the latest scientific information on the Omicron variant, have changed the testing and quarantine policy with effect from 10 January 2022.

In this new testing and quarantine policy, self-testing has become increasingly important. Self-tests are available in supermarkets and pharmacies. For people who benefit from an increased allowance, self-tests are available in pharmacies for €1 per test (a maximum of 4 self-tests per person every 14 days).

description:
In principle, travelling is allowed, provided that the possible measures on your return to Belgium are respected (always fill in the PLF and, if necessary, also fill in the self-assessment, go into quarantine and get tested). However, travel is not recommended to certain destinations or increased vigilance is required.

However, entry into the country of destination also depends on the consent of the country in question.

The FPS Foreign Affairs uses colour codes on its home page to indicate whether travel to a particular country or zone is possible. On this website, you will find a map and a table, showing the same information, as well as detailed information about each country. Below are the COVID-19 colours, based on information from CELEVAL and the FPS Public Health: Select and click on a country or region. The corresponding measures appear. Then click on the country name for detailed travel advice. Please consult this advice before and during your trip.

The following colour codes are used:
- red
- orange
- Light Orange
- Green

Travel advice is highly subject to change and travel to a destination may be discouraged at any time. If you are planning to make an essential journey abroad, it is highly recommended to consult the travel advice from Foreign Affairs, which is continually updated: https://diplomatie.belgium.be/en/services/travelling_abroad/travel_advice_by_country
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgian authorities declared on Wednesday, March 11, 2020, that as part of a "Lockdown" policy in the Brussels-Capital Region, visits to retirement homes deemed "non-essential" have been prohibited until March 31, 2020.

However, the Brussels nursing homes which depend on the Flemish Community are not affected and are applying the measures announced on Tuesday, namely a limitation of visiting hours and a ban on access to children under 16.

description: Beginning on March 18, 2020, and continuing until May 5, 2020, the Belgian Government enforced a "Lockdown" strategy that required all individuals to remain in their homes and permitted them to leave their residences only for specific reasons.: access to ATMs at banks and post offices; have access to medical care; provide assistance and care to the elderly, minors, people with disabilities, and vulnerable people; make business trips, including the home-to-work trip; or do physical activity, walk with one friend or with members of the same household. Funerals, as well as religious or civil marriage ceremonies, are also still allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
The government of Belgium implemented a "Lockdown" policy from April 5, 2020, until April 5, 2022, that mandates citizens to remain in their homes as much as possible and limit contact outside their immediate family in order to prevent the spread of disease:

Except to go to work
Except for essential travel (to the doctor, food shops, post office, bank, pharmacy, to refuel or to help people in need)
Outdoor exercise is allowed and even recommended. You can exercise together with family members living under the same roof and together with one friend. Trips with family members living under the same roof are allowed. It is important to keep a reasonable distance.
Larger gatherings of people are not allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium has implemented a "Lockdown" policy from April 17, 2020, until May 5, 2020, which requires all individuals are mandated to stay home, and can only leave their residence for the following exceptions: access to ATMs at banks and post offices; have access to medical care; provide assistance and care to the elderly, minors, people with disabilities and vulnerable people; make business trips, including the home-to-work trip; or to do physical activity, walk with one friend or with members of the same household. Work as part of essential or volunteering services is also allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
April 15th: Previously, no visitors were in allowed in Belgian nursing homes. From April 21st onward, however, residents of residential facilities – i.e. rest and care homes or centres for people with disabilities – will be allowed to be visited by a pre-designated person. 
The condition is that the person in question has not shown any symptoms of the disease in the past two weeks. It must always be the same person. The residential facilities will be able to organise these visits themselves. These rules will also apply to people who live in isolation and are unable to move around.

It is unclear when this policy is slated to end.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Belgium: Starting from May 18, 2020, until May 20, 2020, all individuals are mandated to stay home as part of a "Lockdown" policy except for the following: to attend the activities and establishments now open, to access ATMs and postal services, access medical services, attend to personal matters, participate in assistance to older individuals, minors or persons with disabilities, take care of animals, go to work, participate in a volunteering program, go for a short exercise activity.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: During the period between May 20, 2020, and June 7, 2020, a "Lockdown" policy was in effect in Belgium which required all individuals to stay at home or in a secondary residence of which they have been owners for at least one year. Individuals can only still leave for the following reasons: in order to participate in indoor or outdoor religious, cultural or physical activities as allowed, access banknote distributors and post offices; access medical care; respond to family needs; provide assistance and care to the elderly, minors, people with disabilities and vulnerable persons; take care of animals; perform business trips, including the home-work trip; participate in volunteering, exercise, or make trips in the context of the sale and rental of real estate.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Belgium: October 30th, 2020: As of November 2nd 2020, families are allowed to have only 1 close contact (not living with them) in their home at a time, no other visits are allowed. People living alone can have 1 other person as well as their close contact as long as they do not come at the same time. 
This policy will be in place until December 13th, 2020, where the government will reassess.

description: Curfews extended in Belgium. On Friday, November 27, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo announced that current lockdown measures will be adapted, with some measures being extended and others eased. All non-essential shops will be permitted to reopen from Tuesday, December 1. People are required to shop alone and can only stay in a shop for 30 minutes. Museums and swimming pools can also reopen, providing they follow health guidelines. However, bars, restaurants, and other businesses in the hospitality sector will remain closed until at least January 15, 2021. The same applies to hairdressers, beauticians, and other personal care services. The current ban on gatherings and curfew measures  from midnight to 05 00  local time  Flandersand from 22 00 to 06 00 in Wallonia and the Brussels Capital region  remain in force
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Since Thursday 12 March 2020, Belgium has been in the “federal phase of crisis management”.

The government is assisted by experts in various fields. These experts advise the government on the measures to be taken. These experts sit together in an evaluation cell (CELEVAL).
Celeval is chaired by the FPS Public Health and consists of:

Health experts
Virologists
Economists
Psychologists
Behavioural experts
Communication experts
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, 12 March: Given the major impact of this pandemic on the entire socio-economic fabric, various crisis units have been put together to operationalise the crisis management:

The Legal Units are responsible for drafting the legal texts and providing answers to various legal questions raised in the context of this complex crisis management.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 12, 2020, the Belgian Government combined several crisis units to form a new task force that would handle crisis management in response to the significant effects of the pandemic on the entire socio-economic structure:
The Operational Unit, coordinated by the NCCN. Via the on-call service (24/7), this unit facilitates the flow of information between the authorities, ensures that the crisis infrastructures are fully operational, and guarantees that the crisis units will be alerted if necessary.
This Operational Unit would operate until March 14, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Belgium,12 March 2020: Given the major impact of this pandemic on the entire socio-economic fabric, various crisis units have been put together to operationalize crisis management until 14 March 2020:

The Task Force Integrated Police coordinates the actions of the police services. Other units have been activated to answer various frequently asked questions and to verify the translations of the published texts.

description:
Belgium, 12 March 2020: Given the major impact of this pandemic on the entire socio-economic fabric, various crisis units have been put together until March 14, 2020, to operationalise the crisis management:
The Socio-economic Unit is chaired by the FPS Economy and is made up of representatives of the Ministers for the Economy, Employment and Public Health and for SMEs, as well as from the FPS Economy, Employment, and Labour, Mobility, Social Security and from the Government Department (POD) Social Integration. It carries out analyses and provides advice on the socio-economic impact of the measures already taken or that will be taken.

description:
Since the start of this pandemic, on March 12, 2020, the political authorities have taken decisions based on the recommendations of health experts in this field.

The National Security Council (NSC), which essentially consists of the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Ministers, has been extended to include the Ministers-President of the Regions and Communities. This collegiate body makes the policy decisions for managing the crisis until March 14, 2020.

description:
Belgium, 12 March 2020: Given the major impact of this pandemic on the entire socio-economic fabric, various crisis units have been put together until March 14, 2020, to operationalise the crisis management: 
The Information Unit is jointly chaired by the FPS Public Health and the NCCN. It ensures the coordination of all local, regional, community, and federal authorities so that the crisis communication strategies and actions are coherent. It provides strategic advice to the competent authorities by basing its actions on the identified information needs of the public.

description: On 19 March 2020, a social emergency task force was set up in the Walloon Region in Belgium. In the context of the coronavirus epidemic, the task force aims to respond to issues that impact vulnerable groups.  It is coordinated by the cabinet of the Minister-President and consists of representatives of all Walloon Ministers, as well as representatives of the RWLP, the Federation of Public Social Welfare Centres  (CPAS), the Federation of Social Services (FDSS), the Walloon Public Service and the Walloon Agency for Quality of Life (AViQ). Depending on the topics, other stakeholders will also be consulted. This task force was set up in collaboration with the Walloon Network against Poverty (RWLP).

description:
Belgium, the law of 27 March 2020 empowering the King to take measures to fight against the spread of COVID-19.

In order to enable the Belgium to respond to the COVID-19 epidemic or pandemic and to manage its consequences, the King may, by decree deliberated in the Council of Ministers, take the measures to, in accordance with the fundamental principles of independence and impartiality, and taking into account the rights of defence of litigants, adapt jurisdiction, operation, the procedure, including statutory time limits, of the Commission's Administrative Litigation Division State and administrative courts in order to ensure the proper functioning of these bodies and more particularly the continuity of the administration of justice and their other missions.

description: In Belgium, on April 8, 2020, the Federal Minister for Poverty Reduction and Minister of Social Inclusion announced that they will set up a new task force on vulnerable groups that would function until April 15, 2020. The task force aims to assess the impact of the COVID-19 policies on vulnerable groups, determine which groups fall outside the scope of socio-economic measures, and suggest additional socio-economic measures accordingly. The task force consists of the Federal Ministers for Poverty Reduction and Social Inclusion and the Regional Ministers for Poverty and Social Action.

Belgium, 11 May 2020. Mental health working group to advise Belgium’s government on deconfinement plan. 

A newly formed mental health working group will advice the group in charge of Belgium’s deconfinement plan (GEES), Professor Elke Van Hoof announced.

Their task will be to address the psychological aspect of the crisis. The GEES has been asking for support on mental health issues and the social impact of the crisis.

description: On November 16, 2020, the Interministerial Conference on Public Health in Belgium stated that they will establish a new task force until December 1, 2020, to assist with the vaccination program, in addition to their other vaccination goals. The task force is called "Operationalising Covid-19 Vaccination Strategy" and will decide on necessary actions and assist with realizing the strategy by coordination. It will consist of scientists, representatives from federal and provincial authorities, crisis managers, and representatives from companies and technical working groups. It will be led by Dirk Ramaekers. Within the task force, there will be a part dedicated to societal debate and communication, led by Yvon Englert.

description:
Belgium: On January 15, 2021, at the request of the minister of public health, Frank Vandenbroucke, the national government started the project Community Health Workers that seeks to promote the available health care in relation to Covid-19. 
50 health care workers, mostly social workers, will be deployed to be the link between vulnerable groups and the health care system. Their role will be to better the access to the health care system, help vulnerable groups understand and use the health care system, and point out the inequalities and structural issues within the health care system, especially in relation to issues pertaining to Covid-19. 
The project is funded with a 2. 975.000 euros grant. The project is set to end at the end of December 2021.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

The policy refers to any grant that was awarded before October 1, 2020, by any organization that provides grants in the Walloon Region of Belgium.

description: Between April 30, 2020, and September 30, 2020, Belgium’s Walloon Government enacted a policy, which states that if the Social Action Council cannot meet between May 4 and September 30, 2020, due to COVID-19 and its reasons are documented, the Permanent Bureau may take over its powers after getting permission from the government. This is only allowed if it is necessary to maintain public services during the COVID-19 health crisis, and if it is urgent and essential.

description: As of 11 May 2020 contact tracing is fully operational in the Flemish Region of Belgium (or Flanders): "After a start-up phase, contact investigations in Flanders are ready to call people across Flanders on an unprecedented scale, to question contacts and to provide advice on how to prevent contamination. Today, about 735 employees started to conduct telephone contact inquiries. In addition, employees of various health insurance funds are ready to strengthen the call centres with advice and to start home visits in the coming days when telephone contact investigations fail."  (Kept on 1 as the other main region (Wallonia) will follow on 18 May 2020.

description: On July 15, 2021, the Belgian government, to support restaurants, cafes, clubs, and pubs, announced that it would reimburse businesses for the costs of beer that had passed its expiration date during the closure of cafes and restaurants in the period from June 1, 2020, to October 30, 2020.

description: Belgium introduced a royal decree on June 4, 2020, that created a "compensation fund for volunteer COVID-19 victims" to provide compensation to individuals and their families who have been volunteering in the public health sector and have been impacted by Covid-19 between March 10, 2020, and July 1, 2020. In case of the death of a volunteer, their spouse received 18,651 euros, the ex-spouse receiving maintenance payments got 9,325.50 euros, and children receiving child support got 15,542.50 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 29, 2020, to comply with a European Commission decision, the Belgian Government declared that from June 11 to September 1, 2020, it would exempt medical devices or products useful in the fight against COVID-19 delivered into Belgian territory from import duties and VAT (value-added tax).

description: On July 15, 2020, the Belgian government announced that it would grant tax reductions to residents who acquired stocks or shares of companies with a sharp decrease in their turnover following the COVID-19 pandemic between March 14, 2020, and December 31, 2020. description:
As of November 12, 2020, in Belgium, the amount of the financial contribution corresponds to 30% of the turnover achieved during the third or fourth quarter of 2019.

The financial intervention is at least 3,000 euros and is limited as follows: 5,000 euros if the number of employees is 0; 10,000 euros if the number of employees is greater than 0 and less than 10; 20,000 euros if the number of employees is equal to or greater than 10 and less than 50; 40,000 euros if the number of employees is equal to or greater than 50.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On November 23, 2020, the Brussels-Capital Government in Belgium announced that the United College, the executive branch of the Common Community Commission, an entity that governs matters common to the French and Flemish communities, will continue to exercise special powers in matters relating to the COVID-19 pandemic. It would be able to authorized to repeal, supplement, amend, or replace the regulations of the Federal Government and determine the administrative and criminal penalties applicable for their violation.

description: This decree from March 20, 2020, authorizes the government of the Region of Brussels-Capital to take any needed measures to combat the pandemic, and by doing so can override, supplement, modify or replace the ordinance provisions in force regarding adaptation of legal texts relating to the deadlines or areas impacted by the crisis; the management of the socio-economic effects of the pandemic; the measures related to prevention and safety in the regional territory; urgent health measures in relation to regional matters; and measures relating to the regional civil service unless June 20, 2020. UPDATE: On November 23, 2020, the Government of the Brussels-Capital Region in Belgium extended the time period of its special powers by two months.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: The Brussels-Capital Region Parliament in Belgium empowered itself to prevent the consequences of COVID-19

description: Beginning on December 24th, 2020, and continuing until September 30th, 2021, Belgium's Walloon Government is implementing one-off and exceptional COVID-19 aid in the amount of 150 euros for gas and 50 euros for electricity that is granted to residential customers. One-off and exceptional COVID-19 aid is granted in the amount of 230 euros in electricity and 135 euros in gas to the residential customer whose energy supply has passed to the network operator following the exceeding of the 40-day period. This period is the time frame within which the company supplying gas or electricity to a residential customer must provide their consumption data to the network operator.

description:
The Belgian authorities have continued the information campaigns since the start of the pandemic and kept communicating about the measures needed to stop the spread of the virus. The campaign, which the FPS Chancellery of the Prime Minister was coordinating at a federal level, has come about in collaboration with the FPS Public Health and the National Crisis Centre, in consultation with the communities and regions and with their full cooperation.

The priority was to remind the population at large of the most critical messages. A particular website has been set up to publish the epidemic report every day. Details of the data have been available to the public since 15 March. Other public health messages, such as respecting hygiene measures, respecting social distancing, respecting safety measures, and persevering and staying calm, was disseminated via radio and TV slots, social media, Internet banners, posters or screens in public places, in bus shelters, supermarkets, pharmacies, and on cash machines. All of these messages were in the three national languages of French, Dutch, German, and another thirty languages [38]. Moreover, the messages via radio, print, Internet, or social media adopt the style, colors, and tone of the messaging from the Crisis Centre and the FPS Public Health in order to maintain a coherent and effective approach to all the government’s communication efforts
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

The website, www.coronavirus.brussels, enables Brussels inhabitants to get official information about the virus, as the platform shows the latest news on the subject and gives details of the health measures to be taken, as well as any specific arrangements made by the Brussels authorities.

description:
Belgium, 23 September 2020.

Belgium has adapted the third phase of risk management, and the Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès announced 6 golden rules stressing the importance of sticking to them (wash your hands, keep your distance, limit close contacts, preferably do your activities outside, think about the vulnerable, follow the rules on gatherings). 

The government will also launch the Coronalert smartphone app on 30 September to notify people on contact tracing and advise on the steps how protect yourself and others.

description:
Belgium: November 27th, 2020: 
Belgium's federal government launched a new campaign, "1 Team of 11 Million Players", which plays on the country's love for soccer/football, to help people persevere through the Covid-19 second wave. The campaign urges people to continue to follow and keep track of the strict covid guidelines in order to minimise the spread of covid. The campaign's message is that only together will Belgium defeat Covid-19. The campaign will be spread through social media, all major TV channels, and national newspapers. The campaign will also put up a tifo (tribune clothe, often used in soccer/football to support teams) in Antwerp and Brussels. The campaign will run until the end of January.

description: As of 12th April, Belgium announces that members of staff without symptoms who have tested positive can continue to work at a COVID department, but solely where no other solution is possible in other words, where there are staff shortages. If there are sufficient staff, or the preconditions cannot be met, then the person concerned must stay at home, just as they should if they were to develop symptoms.

description: Regarding travel, according to a "Quarantine" policy from August 1, 2020, all persons arriving on Belgian territory after a stay abroad of more than 48 hours must complete the Passenger Locator Form, which can be used to check where the traveler has gone. In addition: Anyone returning from a red zone should be tested and quarantined, even if he/she shows no symptoms; If the person returns from an orange zone, it is a recommendation. However, this recommendation should be taken seriously, especially if the person returning from an orange zone has had high-risk contacts; In addition, citizens are asked to actively participate in contact tracing with the regional call center managers, which makes it possible to contact everyone.

description: Regarding travel, according to a "Quarantine" policy from August 1, 2020, all persons arriving on Belgian territory after a stay abroad of more than 48 hours must complete the Passenger Locator Form, which can be used to check where the traveler has gone. In addition: Anyone returning from a red zone should be tested and quarantined, even if he/she shows no symptoms; If the person returns from an orange zone, it is a recommendation. However, this recommendation should be taken seriously, especially if the person returning from an orange zone has had high-risk contacts; In addition, citizens are asked to actively participate in contact tracing with the regional call center managers, which makes it possible to contact everyone.

description: As of 18th September, Belgium updated its list of countries and regions from which returning travelers have to undergo mandatory quarantine and test. Andorra; Austria: province of Vienna; Croatia : provinces of Split-Dalmatia, Brod-Posavina, Zadar and Sibenik-Knin, Virovitica-Podravina, Lika-Senj, Dubrovnik-Neretva and Požega-Slavonia; Czech Republic: regions of Prague, Central Bohemia, Southwest, Northeast, Southeast; France: Ville de Paris ; Departments Ain, Alpes-Maritimes, Aveyron, Bouches-du-Rhône, Corse-du-Sud, Côte-d’Or, Essonne, Gard, Gers, Guadeloupe,  French Guyana, Gironde, Haute-Corse, Haute-Garonne, Hauts-de-Seine, Hérault, Ille-et-Vilaine, Indre-et-Loire, Isère, Loire, Loiret, Maine-et-Loire, Martinique, Nord, Pas-de-Calais, Puy-de-Dôme, Pyrénées-Atlantiques, Pyrénées-Orientales, Réunion, Rhône, Sarthe, Seine-et-Marne, Seine-Maritime, Seine-Saint-Denis, Tarn-et-Garonne, Val-d’Oise, Val-de-Marne, Var, Vaucluse, Vienne, Yvelines; Hungary: Budapest; Monaco; Netherlands: Provinces of South-Holland and North-Holland; Romania; Spain except the islands of Tenerife, El Hierro, La Gomera and La Palma; Switzerland: cantons of Freiburg and Vaud; United Kingdom: North West England are added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The National Security Council shortened and simplified quarantine from 23rd September 2020:
- If people present with symptom(s), they should self-isolate immediately for 7 days and contact their doctor to get tested as soon as possible. If the test is positive, they must continue the quarantine and if the test is negative, they can get out of quarantine if their clinical condition allows them to do so.
- For asymptomatic people who have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive, as soon as they find out about this or are contacted by contact tracing, they should self-isolate for 7 days from the last day of close contact with the infected person. This only in case of close contact with a positive person. They then need to get tested on the 5th day. If the test is positive, the quarantine is extended for another seven days. If the test is negative, the quarantine stops after the 7th day.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Belgium, 23 September 2020.
The mandatory quarantine period will be reduced from 14 days to one week. People who show Covid-19 symptoms still have to contact their doctor. 

On day 5 of the quarantine, a new test can be taken. If negative, people may leave quarantine after the week is up. If positive, the quarantine will be extended to the full 2 weeks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium to Reimpose Compulsory Quarantine for Travellers From COVID-19 High-Risk Countries. 

Belgium has reintroduced compulsory quarantine rules for all internationals who wish to enter the country during the year-end period from any country considered profoundly affected by the Coronavirus situation.

From December 18, all travellers will still have to fill in the Passenger Locator Form (PLF), but people coming from a red zone will also be required to go into quarantine for ten days, with a test on day seven. If the test is negative, you can leave quarantine.

All persons who spent up to 48 hours abroad were required to fill in the Passenger Locator Form (PLF), which is a form that requires persons detailed information regarding what they did while abroad. Then, based on the form, travellers received a text message informing them if they had to go under quarantine or not.

From December 18, Belgium authorities would start to examine if returning passengers are following quarantine rules upon their return.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium: December 30th, 2020: The federal government has enforced new quarantine rules. Residents and non-residents, coming from a stay of longer than 48 hours in a red zone must quarantine. The quarantine can only be ended after receiving a negative PCR test, 7 days after they started their quarantine. They must never the less be tested on the first and seventh day of quarantine. Starting on the 2nd of January, travellers will receive a text telling them when to present themselves to a testing centre. 
However, there are three exceptions. First, students can interrupt their quarantine in order to take an exam. Second, critical essential workers can go back to work with a testimonial from their employer. Third, people who travelled due to work can interrupt their quarantine if they have a testimonial from their employer on the reason for travel, this third exception only applies until the 4th of January 2021. 
This policy will be in place until January 15th, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Belgium - On January 15th 2021, new quarantine policy was implemented. People who test positive must quarantine for 7 days. The quarantine ends after 7 days if they didn't have the fever or respiratory problems 3 days prior to the end of the quarantine. 

The quarantine of 7 days is also in place for asymptomatic people who were in contact with people who tested positive and for people who returned from abroad. The quarantine ends after 7 days, if they test negative on the 7th day. If they test positive, the quarantine is to last for another 7 days and the rules described above (for people who tested positive) apply.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Between January 27, 2021, and March 1, 2021, a new "Quarantine" policy was introduced in Belgium that mandates individuals who test positive for Covid-19 to isolate themselves for ten days. After a high-risk contact or travel to Belgium, the quarantine period also remains ten days. This period may be reduced to a minimum of seven days, provided that a negative test has been performed no earlier than seven days after exposure.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 10 January, people who have either already received a booster dose or those who received their last shot of the “basic vaccination” up to five months ago will no longer have to quarantine following a high-risk contact. Meanwhile, for people who have not yet received the booster vaccination or who received their last dose more than five months ago, the quarantine period will be shortened following a high-risk contact: they may leave after four days following a high-risk contact provided that a daily self-test is taken until day seven. These people will also no longer need a PCR test to end quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium is dropping the requirement for fully vaccinated people to self-isolate if they come into close contact with someone infected with COVID-19. The rule applies to anyone who received their second vaccine dose or booster in the last five months but does not apply to unvaccinated people, who must still isolate for 10 days. This period can be cut to seven days, however, with a daily negative antigen test through day 10, broadcaster VRT reported. For vaccinated people who fall outside of the five-month gap, they must also isolate for 10 days but can be released on day four with a daily negative antigen test through day 10. The new "Quarantine" policy, backed by federal and regional health ministers on Tuesday, will come into effect on January 10, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: People who test positive for Covid-19 from 27 January 2021must  isolate themselves for 10 days. After a high-risk contact or travel to Belgium, the quarantine period also remains ten days. This period may be reduced to a minimum of seven days, provided that a negative test has been performed no earlier than seven days after exposure. UPDATE: A person who tests positive will have to isolate themselves for 7 days (not 10 days) and 3 additional days of vigilance if they do not develop symptoms or have mild complaints.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On Tuesday 17 March, the National Security Council, which has been expanded to include the Ministers-President, decided to take additional measures. On the one hand, these measures are based on the evolution of the spread of Covid-19 in Belgium.
Companies - regardless of size - are obliged to organize teleworking for every function where this is possible, without exception.
For those for whom this organization is not possible, social distancing will be strictly respected. This rule applies to both the performance of the work and the transport organized by the employer. If it is impossible for companies to meet these obligations, they must close their doors.
If the authorities establish that the social distancing measures are not being complied with, the company will in the first instance be fined a heavy one; in case of non-compliance after the sanction, the company will have to close.

The measures set out below will enter into force at noon on Wednesday 18 March and shall be maintained until 5 April. The situation will continue to be assessed on a daily basis and further changes may be made as the situation evolves.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

As announced on March 10, the evolution of the spread of the coronavirus is assessed every day, as the situation is constantly changing. Shops will be open during the week, but not on weekends. UPDATE: The original policy stated that shops will be allowed to open in the week, but will be closed on weekends. The new policy states that all non-essential shops will be closed.

description:
Belgium cancels all activities, regardless of their size and whether they are public or private. Also, public spaces will be closed. More specifically:
Clubs, cafés and restaurants stay closed. Hotels remain open, except for their possible restaurant. Home delivery and drive-in are allowed.
Shops remain open all week, but not on weekends. Grocery stores and pharmacies remain open, even on weekends. 
All recreational activities are suspended.

These measures apply until May 3rd. UPDATE: The original closure of non-essential businesses, gatherings and actvities was set to last until April 3rd, then extended to April 19th and now extended to May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down

description:
In Belgium, all non-essential businesses must close except DIY shops and garden centres. 1,5m distance should be maintained by fulfilling the following conditions: 1 customer per 10m² and the customers may only be present for a maximum of 30 minutes. If possible, people have to go alone to the store.
Policy was announced on April 15 and set to lat until May 3rd. UPDATE: DIY shops and garden centers are allowed to open from 15th April, under the same conditions as supermarkets (i.e.: 1 customer per 10m² and the customers may only shop for a maximum of 30 minutes. If possible, people have to go alone to the store). This policy is now set to last until May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Belgium, Wallonia, 4 May 2020. 
In its deconfinement strategy, the Walloon government has decided that technical inspection stations can once again offer their services, since Monday 4 May, to all inspection services and for all vehicles.

This reopening is accompanied by "strict health measures", as announced by the Walloon authorities in a press release:
- these checks will only be carried out by appointment;
- only one person is allowed per vehicle.
- wearing a mask is mandatory for all customers.
- all customers must strictly respect the instructions communicated at the station, the ground markings and the safety distances of a minimum of 1.5 meters with staff and other customers.
- inspectors will be equipped with masks and gloves.
- payments will be made only electronically.

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

Yet, many non-essential businesses must remain closed still. These include:
- Markets (only individual market stalls (food and non-food) will be allowed by the local authorities and at the usual locations)
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls
- Recreational, cultural and tourist sites 
- Hairdressers, beautycians and other businesses that require physical contact

description:
On May 13th, Belgium announced to relax certain restrictions on mass gatherings and activities. While bars and restaurants remain closed, sports and leisure activities can be resumed under certain conditions. 
More specifically, nature attractions, such as zoos, will also be allowed to reopen, provided:
- they introduce an online or phone ticketing system to restrict access to the public
- they draw up a circulation plan 
- that cafeterias and restaurants remain closed, as well as attractions and playgrounds. 

Regular outdoor group sports training and lessons may resume, provided:
- social distancing is adhered to and a coach is present
- groups do not exceed 20 persons 
- sports reopen only when all possible measures are taken to guarantee the safety of the sportsmen and sportswomen.

Besides, weddings and funerals are allowed again, provided that:
- social distances rules are respected
- no more than 30 guests attend
- no reception is being organised

These measures enter into force on May 18th and are part of Belgium's exit strategy phase 2.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
From 8 June, 2020 in Belgium non-contact sports activities can be resumed, both indoor and outdoor, amateur or professional, league and training. Gyms and fitness rooms may also be reopened, subject to protocol.

However:

Contact sports (e.g. judo, boxing, football, etc.) should always be limited to "contactless" training.
As far as sports facilities are concerned, the protocols will also have to be followed. Changing rooms and showers will still not be accessible.
Swimming pools, saunas and wellness centres have to remain closed at this stage.

description:
Belgium will go ahead with the next phase of its exit plan out of the lockdown from 1 July, announced Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès during a press conference on Wednesday. Phase 4: 1 July

The 6 golden rules will continue to apply. Here’s a refresher on what they are.

You can have closer contact with 15 people, instead of the previous 10. This can be 15 different people every week.

Swimming pools, wellness centres, amusement parks, casinos and gaming halls can reopen. Reception halls can also reopen, but for a maximum of 50 people, if they apply the protocols.

description: The National Security Council, expanded with the prime ministers, met on 23 July to take stock of the health situation in our country and to take the necessary measures. The National Security Council has adopted a series of measures that will apply across the country from Saturday, July 25. The customers of the catering industry will be asked to leave an email address or a telephone number , so that they can be notified in time in the event of an infection. This information will be destroyed after 14 days and cannot be used for any other purpose than the fight against the Coronavirus.

description:
Face masks in all busy places, registering at restaurants or pubs, extra travel documents: corona measures extended from July 25, 2020.
Night shops are to close earlier, pubs and restaurants will have to register all customers and keep details for two weeks, and face masks will become mandatory in busy places like markets or shopping streets across the country: Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès of Belgium has announced stricter "Restriction and Regulation of Businesses" policy after a new meeting of the National Security Council with federal and regional ministers and health experts, considering the worsening Covid statistics. Unless local authorities have stated otherwise, the new measures will apply as of Saturday.

Belgium: October 16th, 2020: The Consultative Committee has decided to move the entire country into alert level 4 from October 19th, 2020 until November 19th, 2020 (one month). Restrictions for businesses include: 

- Markets and fairs will remain open, but no selling of food and drink and flea markets, bric-a-brac markets and small Christmas markets are forbidden. 
- Teleworking will be mandatory wherever possible. 
- Cafes and restaurants will be closed, picking-up limited to before 10 pm with a ban on selling alcohol past 8 pm.

description:
The Expat Welcome Desk informs expats in Brussels about the latest measures taken in Belgium to limit the spread of Covid-19. In Brussels Region: closure of cultural venues (museums, exhibitions halls, etc.) and closure of recreational facilities including amusement parks, cinemas, betting agencies, casinos, etc.
Night clubs are closed, same as coffee shops, cafeterias, bars. Shops are allowed to open only one person to do the shopping (+1 minor). Only disabled people are allowed to be accompanied by an adult. All shops close at 8 pm.  Restaurants are also closed but take-away meals authorised until 10 pm.

description:
Belgium, 28 October 2020.

The Minister of the Interior of Belgium has announced emergency measures to limit the spread of the COVID-19 on 28 October 2020. 

Companies and associations offering goods or services to consumers should inform customers and staff members of the measures and provide appropriate training for workers. They also should guarantee a distance of 1.5 meters between each person or one customer per 10 m2, where clients can enter for a maximum period of 30 minutes or as long as is customary in the event of an appointment.

If the area accessible to customers is less than 20 m2, it is allowed to accommodate two guests, provided that a distance of 1.5 meters is guaranteed between each person;

Masks and other means of personal protection are in all times highly recommended. 

The companies and enterprises should provide staff and customers with the products necessary for the hygiene of hands. They are required to disinfect regularly the establishment and the equipment used and ensure good ventilation. 

Customers and staff can report possible coronavirus contamination COVID-19 to facilitate contact tracing;
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Maximum number of employees,Size of store limited (e.g. stores smaller than 800 sq meters),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description:
Belgium, Flanders, October 28th. 
Flanders is further tightening the federal measures to stop the spread of the coronavirus in the Region, announced Flemish Minister-President Jan Jambon. 
People are asked to telework to the maximum of their capacity. 
Jambon did not provide an end date for the restrictions, but did say that they would be in force for at least three weeks.

description:
Wallonia, Belgium, 30 October 2020.

The Wallonia Government has announced on 30 October that the services should be carried out by teleworking 100% without requiring staff to be present at their usual place of work during one or more days per week.

However, this instruction does not prevent benefits face-to-face occasionally to ensure the continuity of missions (picking up and processing mail, participate in essential meetings, presence for repairs or interventions, etc ...).

When teleworking is not possible, work is provided face-to-face while ensuring strict compliance sanitary rules. In addition, when a staff member experiences for family or personal reasons difficulties in teleworking, it may be allowed by his/her hierarchical superior (rank A4 or A5) to work face-to-face.

The Decree has its effect until 19 November 2020.

description:
Belgium: October 30th, 2020: As of November 2nd, the Consultative Committee put in place new regulations for businesses:

- Holiday parks and campsites will be closed as of the 3rd of November. All activities will be shut down, including restaurants, bars, and swimming pools.
- Hotels and B&Bs can remain open, but restaurants and bars must close. Hotel and B&B meals must be served in the room.

These will be in place until December 13th, 2020 when the Consultative Committee will reassess.

description:
The Federal Government and the Governments of the federated entities of Belgium decided in the Consultative Committee to proceed to a stricter lockdown on October 30th.
- Holiday parks and campsites will be completely closed from Tuesday morning 3 November. Indoor and outdoor activities in holiday parks are stopped until that date. Swimming pools, restaurants and bars will be closed. Meals must be consumed inside the holiday homes, as a family.
- Non-essential shops have to close, but they can organize pick-up and home delivery of goods ordered in advance. There must be no access to the shop when picking up goods.
- To maintain a level playing field, supermarkets and markets (<200 persons) must limit their product range to what is on offer in the essential shops.

The measures will apply for one and a half months, until Sunday 13 December 2020. For non-essential shops, the Consultative Committee will perform an evaluation on 1 December.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

- To maintain a level playing field, supermarkets and markets (<200 persons) must limit their product range to what is on offer in the essential shops.

The measures will apply for one and a half months, until Sunday 13 December 2020. For non-essential shops, the Consultative Committee will perform an evaluation on 1 December.

description:
The Federal Government and the Governments of the federated entities of Belgium decided in the Consultative Committee to proceed to a stricter lockdown on October 30th.
- Holiday parks and campsites will be completely closed from Tuesday morning 3 November. Indoor and outdoor activities in holiday parks are stopped until that date. Swimming pools, restaurants and bars will be closed. Meals must be consumed inside the holiday homes, as a family.
- Non-essential shops have to close, but they can organize pick-up and home delivery of goods ordered in advance. There must be no access to the shop when picking up goods.
- To maintain a level playing field, supermarkets and markets (<200 persons) must limit their product range to what is on offer in the essential shops.

The measures will apply for one and a half months, until Sunday 13 December 2020. For non-essential shops, the Consultative Committee will perform an evaluation on 1 December.

description:
Belgium: October 30th, 2020: As of November 2nd, the Consultative Committee put in place new business restrictions:

- All non-essential stores must close. Pick-up and deliveries are allowed, but when picking up goods, no access to the store is permitted.
-All non-medical contact professions must stop operating, including hairdressers, make-up artists, wellness centers, massage parlours, and beauty salons.

These will be in place until December 13th, 2020 when the Consultative Committee will reassess.

UPDATE: All non-essential stores can open on December 1st, 2020 with restrictions, including the mandatory washing of hands, mask-wearing, and social distancing, visible prevention measure guidelines, and hand sanitiser must be used before entering stores. Furthermore, shoppers must shop individually and there is a maximum shopping time of 30 minutes per individual. Non-medical contact businesses must remain closed until the 13th of December, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy closed all non-essential businesses and non-medical contact businesses, but in the change of the policy, non-essential businesses are allowed to open while non-medical contact businesses must remain closed. Furthermore, the original restrictions for both were to last until December 13th, non-essential businesses can open on the 1st of December, while non-medical contact businesses must remain closed until the 13th of December 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Personal Grooming Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, 27 November 2020.

On November 27, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo announced that current lockdown measures will be adapted, with some measures being extended and others eased. All non-essential shops will be permitted to reopen from Tuesday, December 1. People are required to shop alone and can only stay in a shop for 30 minutes. Museums and swimming pools can also reopen, providing they follow health guidelines. However, bars, restaurants, and other businesses in the hospitality sector will remain closed until at least January 15, 2021. The same applies to hairdressers, beauticians, and other personal care services.

description:
Belgium, December 18th. 

The Consultative Committee has decided that it is not possible to relax any of the measures in force. There will be additional measures and stricter controls of the existing rules will be put in place.

- Cities and municipalities are asked to continue and, if necessary, intensify their efforts against unauthorised gatherings, shopping for pleasure and cross-border shopping.

- Shopping must be done individually and may only last up to 30 minutes.

- Trade unions and employers are asked to propose stricter measures, in particular to avoid high-risk situations.

- The Committees for Protection and Prevention at Work will assist in monitoring compliance with sanitary measures and social distancing rules.

description:
Belgium, February 5th. 
The Consultative Committee took note of the Judgement of the Council of State of 2 February regarding holiday homes in holiday parks, bungalow parks and campsites. In accordance with the Judgement, they will be able to reopen their activities from 8 February under the same restrictive conditions as other forms of accommodation. The Consultative Committee confirmed its earlier decision to allow home visits as part of real estate activities by professional estate agents from 13 February onwards.

description:
Belgium, March 24th.
Continued mandate to work from home if possible until at least April 25. The controls on mandatory working from home will be ramped up and tightened. Employers must keep records showing the schedule of who will be present in the workplace and when. Public governments also need to comply with the obligations to work from home.

Importance of the basic rules:
The Consultative Committee reiterates the importance of: 
- complying with the applicable health measures by the population,
- strict enforcement by the police and inspection services of these measures, 
- mandatory working from home, as well as its strict enforcement by the inspection services,
- measures taken by local governments to avoid crowding in busy areas. 

The Ministerial Decree is valid until April 25.

description:
Belgium lays out rules to reopen terraces from 8 May.

Belgium's authorities have agreed on the rules and frameworks for the planned relaxations of the coronavirus measures, announced Prime Minister Alexander De Croo.

"The progress of the vaccination campaign allows us to say that, on 8 May the so-called 'outdoor plan' can come into force, meaning the terraces can open," he said.

From 8 May, the terraces of the hospitality sector will be allowed open.

- Up to four customers per table can be served. Exceptions will be made larger for households.
- Terraces can open between 8:00 AM and 10:00 PM.
- There is no maximum number of people allowed per terrace, but tables have to be at 1.5 metres distance from each other.
- People have to be served at their table, and all staff have to wear face masks.
- When moving around, to go to the toilet for example, customers also have to wear a mask.

description:
Belgium, May 18th. 
The government of Belgium has set rules to stop the spread of coronavirus concerning sports and leisure places. Although libraries,outdoor playgrounds, museums, zoos, holiday parks, bungalow parks and campings, and musement parks (outdoor areas) are open, other places e.g. cinemas and casinos are closed. 

There are events or shows like theatre, professional sports competitions or concerts which require: 
- A maximum of 50 people may attend.
- You must be seated
- This is only allowed outside.

Organised activities (e.g. a club or an association) can take place in groups of maximum 25 people.
- This is only allowed outside. 
- For children up to 12 years of age, this is allowed inside with a maximum of 10 children.
- There must always be a trainer or supervisor.
- No public is allowed.
- Spending the night is not allowed.

In the event of non-compliance with the measures (provided by the Ministerial Order), sanctions are possible under Article 187 of the law on Civil Security of 15 May 2007, among others.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Regarding restriction & regulation of business in Belgium. These measures are valid until 26 June.

Shops and catering industry

All shops are open.
You are allowed to go shopping with 2 other people. Children up to and including 12 years old should not be taken into account
When you enter the store disinfect your hands first.
Wear a face mask. This is mandatory.
Do you own a shop? Read the guide by the FPS Economy.
Markets are being organized.
You can visit the market in groups of four. Children up to and including 12 years old should not be taken into account. Keep a distance of 1,5 meters from other groups.
You can eat and drink at the market.
Night shops are open until 11:30 PM.
Hairdressers and other non-medical contact professions, such as pedicure and beauty salons, are open.

Bars and restaurants

Cafés and restaurants are open from 5 AM until 11:30 PM.
You are allowed at the table in groups of maximum 4 people or with the people you live with. Children up to and including 12 years old should not be taken into account.
You must remain seated at the table. You do not need to wear a face mask.
If you need to go to the toilet or pay the bill, make sure to wear a face mask.
Do you own a pub or restaurant? Read the guide by the FPS Economy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Between June 9, 2021, and July 1, 2021, Belgium enacted a restriction and regulation of businesses policy stating that catering industry will reopen indoors between 8am and 10pm. The maximum number of people per table is 4 or one household per table. A distance of least 1.5 meters must be maintained between tables. Outdoor catering establishments will be able to remain open until 11.30pm instead of 10pm. The table rules will remain the same: 4 people or one household per table and a distance of 1.5 meters between tables. Parties and receptions: up to 50 people indoors.This is the first step in the summer four-step plan.

description: Starting June 9, 2021, Belgiun enacted a restriction and regulation of businesses policy stating that bars, restaurants and all other businesses in the hospitality industry will be allowed to open their indoor areas to clients. Both the indoor areas and the terraces can already open as early as 5:00 AM, and can stay open until 11:30 PM. The current rules will continue to apply: a maximum of four people at a table (unless your household is bigger), with tables 1.5 metres apart.

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee has released a four-step summer plan that begins on June 9th and is to go until the 1st of September, 2021. The plan is contingent on beds in intensive care filled by covid-19 patients remain below 500 and vaccinations continue as planned. 

The first step is to begin on the 9th of June, 2021. For businesses, the plan mandates that teleworking remain mandatory, with 1 day in the office per week. There are to never be more than 20% of the employees present at the same time. Testing is highly recommended. 
Cinemas, bowling alleys, casinos, fruit machine halls and bookmakers may reopen with ventilation protocols. This is also the case for indoor areas of nature parks, zoos and amusement parks as well as indoor playgrounds, indoor recreation, tropical swimming pools and unmanned tanning beds. 
Fairs and non-professional bric-a-brac and flea markets will also be able to take place again. They must be organised according to the same rules as for markets. 
Fitness centres can reopen with ventilation protocols and the mandatory use of a visible air quality meter. 
Door-to-door sales is permitted again, as are the activities of sex workers.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Belgian government will ease further domestic COVID-19 restrictions from June 9. 

Working from home will remain mandatory where possible, though employees will be permitted to return to the office one day per week. Most businesses and services were previously permitted to reopen subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements. Facemasks remain mandatory in enclosed public spaces and busy outdoor areas as defined by local authorities.

Belgium: The Consultative Committee has released a four-step summer plan that begins on June 9th and is to go until the 1st of September, 2021. The plan is contingent on beds in intensive care filled by covid-19 patients remain below 500 and vaccinations continue as planned. 

Step 1 is to begin on the 9th of June, 2021. For businesses, the plan mandates that teleworking remain mandatory, with 1 day in the office per week. There are to never be more than 20% of the employees present at the same time. Testing is highly recommended. 
Cinemas, bowling alleys, casinos, fruit machine halls and bookmakers may reopen with ventilation protocols. This is also the case for indoor areas of nature parks, zoos and amusement parks as well as indoor playgrounds, indoor recreation, tropical swimming pools and unmanned tanning beds.

description: Between July 1, 2021, and May 1, 2023, Belgium's Government and the federated entities convened the Consultative Committee enacted a restriction and regulation of businesses policy stating that for businesses, teleworking will no longer be mandatory but will still be recommended, as will regular testing and there will be no more restrictions when shopping. This is the Step 2 of the four-step summer plan.

description: Starting April 26, 2021, Belgium's Consultative Committee enacted a restriction and regulation of businesses policy stating that restaurants are allowed to reopen and gatherings of 10 people are permitted. However, conditions for terraces have been put in place. A maximum of 4 people, or one household, are allowed at one table. There must be at least 1.5 meters between tables. Face masks are mandatory for staff and any non-seated customers. You can not order directly from the bar, there is only table seating. Customers can only go inside briefly to use the washroom, pay, or reach the terrace. Opening hours are limited to 8am till 10pm.

description: In response to the spread of the Omicron variant, indoor venues such as cinemas, theaters, concert halls, and conferences will have to close on December 26th. This announcement made on December 22nd will also include public access to stadiums, sporting events, and outdoor venues under tents. However, outdoor Christmas markets are allowed to stay open with a restriction on capacity. While museums, libraries, and sports facilities will be allowed to remain open, amusement parks are required to be closed by the 26th. Shopping will be allowed but only in pairs, excluding children.

description: From 23rd of October, 2020 in Belgium the following establishments remain closed to the public: jacuzzis, hammers and other spa facilities, discos and clubs, reception and celebration halls except for funerals, interior spaces in zoos and animal parks, and amusement parks. UPDATE: Starting from January 28, 2022, the Belgian government announced a policy restricting and regulating businesses which allowed indoor facilities to reopen to the public without any restrictions, including amusement parks, indoor playgrounds, zoos and animal parks, subtropical swimming pools and recreational areas of swimming pools, trampoline parks, bowling, and darts halls, snooker and billiard halls, paintball and laser tag centers, escape rooms, casinos, arcades, and betting shops.

description: As of Feb 15, 2022, Belgian employees will be able to work a four-day week after the government on Tuesday agreed a new labour accord aimed at bringing flexibility to an otherwise rigid labour market. Employees who request it will be able to work up to 10 hours per day if trade unions agree, instead of the maximum 8 now, in order to work one day less per week for the same pay. Belgians will also be able to choose to work more during one week and less the following one, allowing people to better manage their work-private life, in case of co-parenting for example.

description: From 7 March 2022 Belgium will remove almost all its coronavirus restrictions from Monday, ending a requirement to wear masks in almost all places and scrapping the need to show a COVID-19 pass for indoor venues from cafes to sports halls. From Monday, Belgians wanting to dine in a restaurant, drink in a bar or visit a museum or cinema will no longer need to show a COVID pass, proving vaccination, recent recovery from infection or a negative test.

description:
Brussels-Capital Region, Belgium, 16 April 2020.

In context of the COVID-19 health crisis, the government of the Brussels-Capital Region has decided to delay the regional tax relative to tourist lodging and accommodation during the period from 1 January 2020 to 30 June 2020 to ease their financial burden. 

This Order shall take effect on 1 January 2020.

description: Between March 1, 2020, and December 23, 2020, Belgium’s Walloon Government regulated government services by extending the period of time in which trainees can complete professional training organized through the Office for Vocational Training and Employment (Le Forem). The execution of a professional training contract can be suspended between March 1, 2020 and May 31, 2020 for reasons related to COVID-19, and the end date of the contract can be extended by an equivalent period of time to the suspension.

description: On March 1, 2020, Belgium's Walloon Government regulated and restricted a government service policy stating that the Minister of Education has the power to stop giving scholarships for the academic year 2020-2021 or for specific periods within that year, such as the first or second quarters. This decision will depend on how the COVID-19 situation develops. The Minister may also delay giving scholarships for language immersion programs for a few months during the second half of 2020. This policy expires on December 23, 2020.

description:
As announced on March 10, the evolution of the spread of the coronavirus is assessed every day, as the situation is constantly changing. In light of the most recent developments, the National Security Council met on Thursday 12 March in the presence of and in consultation with the Ministers-President. 
These measures are in effect from Friday midnight until 3 April. As before, the ongoing situation will be assessed on a daily basis.

Public transport will continue to function normally, but trips should be limited to only those that are necessary. Flexible working times should prevent overloading public transport.

description: Starting March 18, 2020, Belgium’s Walloon Government enacted a restriction and regulation of government services policy stating that if the Walloon Parliament has to stop working because of Covid-19, then Belgium’s Government can exercise powers normally held by the Walloon Parliament, to make sure public services keep running. They can make new decrees, change old ones, or cancel them. These new decrees might have punishments for people who break them, but the punishments cannot be worse than the ones that already existed.

description:
As announced on March 10, the evolution of the spread of the coronavirus is assessed every day, as the situation is constantly changing. In light of the most recent developments, the National Security Council met on Thursday 12 March in the presence of and in consultation with the Ministers-President. 
These measures are in effect from Friday midnight until 3 April. As before, the ongoing situation will be assessed on a daily basis.

Public transport will continue to function normally, but trips should be limited to only those that are necessary. Flexible working times should prevent overloading public transport. UPDATE: The original policy recommended that public transport must inly be used if necessary. The new policy states that social distancing (1.5 m) should be maintained on public transport.

description:
Belgium, 11 May 2020.

The mayors of Belgium's coastal municipalities will follow the guidelines of the National Security Council for reopening the beaches, despite some earlier grievances.

Additionally, a single uniform framework will be provided in which coastal municipalities can take measures tailored to their own needs, concerning traffic circulation for cars as well as people, a beach plan with a focus on access to the beach, supervised bathing areas from 27 June, and a circulation and terrace plan.

Each municipality will be allowed to implement these plans based on the number of visitors.
