description:
The National Security Council (NSC), extended with the ministers-president had a meeting today, Wednesday 13 May. On the basis of the GEES experts' report, the NSC decided to start phase 2 of the phase-out plan as from 18 May. A second aspect in this phase is culture. The NSC has decided that museums and cultural sights - historic buildings and monuments, castles, citadels - can be reopened as from 18 May, provided they set up an online or telephone ticketing system and take the necessary measures to avoid drawing crowds. Libraries can remain open, under the same conditions as now.
Natural tourist sites, such as zoos, will also be allowed to reopen, provided that they introduce an online or telephone ticketing system to restrict public access, draw up a circulation plan and that cafeterias and restaurants remain closed, as well as any rides and playgrounds.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
Belgium, 27 May 2020.

The Minister of Security and the Interior has announced that playgrounds can be visited, and should be reserved for children up to 12 years old, accommodating a maximum of 20 children at a time, while adults accompanying children respect the rules of social distancing, in particular maintaining a distance of 1.5 meters between each person.

This Order comes into force on May 27, 2020.

description: Starting June 22, 2020, Belgium’s Walloon Government enacted a restriction and regulation of government services policy stating that if the government experiences a financial shortfall in their regular budget due to the impact of the COVID-19 crisis, they will be allowed to operate at a deficit. A maximum limit for the deficit amount that can be incurred in each of the two years: 3% of the total expenditure for the financial year 2020 and 5% of the total expenditure for the financial year 2021.

description:
The Expat Welcome Desk informs expats in Brussels about the latest measures taken in Belgium to limit the spread of Covid-19. In Brussels Region: closure of cultural venues (museums, exhibitions halls, etc.) and closure of recreational facilities including amusement parks, cinemas, betting agencies, casinos, etc.
Night clubs are closed, same as coffee shops, cafeterias, bars. Shops are allowed to open only one person to do the shopping (+1 minor). Only disabled people are allowed to be accompanied by an adult. All shops close at 8 pm.  Restaurants are also closed but take-away meals authorised until 10 pm.

description: Starting January 15, 2021, Belgium’s Walloon Government announced that the second group to receive priority for COVID-19 vaccination includes residents and staff of collective care and support institutions, except for nursing homes. This includes short-term care facilities, places where people get help with daily activities, and places where people go for daytime care. It also includes volunteers, trainees, students, and staff from outside organizations who come to these places to help, as well as people who work in these places in the fields of disability policy, healthcare policy, and social action policy. The decree expires on February 23, 2021.

It also includes volunteers, trainees, students, and staff from outside organizations who come to these places to help, as well as people who work in these places in the fields of disability policy, healthcare policy, and social action policy. The decree expires on February 23, 2021.

description:
Belgium: February 12th, 2021: On the proposition by deputy minister Petra De Sutter, the federal government is providing measures in order to better support federal government workers working from home. 
Measures in six areas will be implemented. The measures are to be put in place to help with burn-out, reinforcing communication within the federal administrations, better image strategy for workers linked to working with the covid-19 pandemic, a new process deciding who works from home, training for administration leaders as well as for collaborators, and the buying of new materials and technology to help handicapped federal workers working from home.

description: The Consultation Committee of Belgium took into account the decision of the Council of State of 2 February concerning holiday homes in holiday parks, bungalow parks and campsites. In accordance with this decision, these parks will be able to resume their activities from 8 February, while following the same restrictive conditions as other types of tourist accommodation. This means, for example, that their restaurants, bars and other communal facilities will remain closed.

description:
Belgium, 19 December 2020.

The Minister of the Interior of Belgium has declared that the Christmas holidays mark the beginning of the high season of winter sports. Since large crowds of people gather on the ski slopes, which makes it difficult to manage crowds of people and the inability to comply with the rules of social distancing, the risk of transmission of the COVID-19 virus is very high. For this reason, ski slopes, ski touring trails, and ski centers must be closed.

This Order comes into force on December 21, 2020.

description:
Citizens are obliged to stay at home in order to avoid as much contact as possible outside their families:
- Outdoor exercise is allowed and even recommended. This can be done with family members who live under the same roof and with a friend. Outings with family members living under the same roof are allowed. It is important to keep a reasonable distance.
- Gatherings are not allowed.
- Except to go to work
- Except for essential travel (to the doctor, food stores, the post office, the bank, the pharmacy, to refuel or to help people in need).

The measures will enter into force on Wednesday 18 March at noon and will be maintained until 5 April.

description:
Belgium, 19 May 2020. 

A maximum of 30 people are allowed to attend the funeral of the deceased from the moment they leave the funeral home until burial or cremation. 

Transportation of the deceased can only be carried out by funeral companies that have received permission to conduct funerals, and intended for placement in the morgue in which they are located. Any conservation of the deceased at home is strictly prohibited.

Visiting periods should be limited to two periods of contemplation lasting for an hour and a half, by appointment, which must be agreed between the funeral parlor and the family of the deceased. The funeral home monitors the observance of social distancing. 

Each funeral company guarantees that the costs associated with funeral arrangements are strictly limited to the service actually provided and without additional costs.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Children under 13 will be allowed to play in public playgrounds again from May 27, 2021, after Belgium authorities were given the green light to reopen them. Only children under the age of 12 will be allowed into the public areas and accompanying adults must keep the mandatory 1.5 metres of social distance between each other. Indoor playgrounds will not be allowed to reopen and outdoor playgrounds or play areas in natural parks or in places like museums or zoos can reopen but a staff member must be present to enforce the rules.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From 8 June, 2020 in Belgium cultural activities may resume without an audience present. Performances with an audience - including cinemas - can be resumed from 1 July, but only subject to specific rules regarding crowd management, such as respecting the safety distance in the audience and a maximum of 200 attendees.

Activities should be organised in such a way as to avoid gatherings of too many people, e.g. outside the venue.

When people take part in cultural and leisure activities, wearing a mask is recommended at all times.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, June 3rd. 
From Monday, when Phase 3 of Belgium's exit plan out of lockdown starts, each person will be allowed to see a maximum of 10 other people per week. These people do not have to be the same ones every time, Belgian Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès stressed during a press conference on Wednesday.

Activities will be allowed to take place again in groups of 10, children included. This applies to all situations, both indoors and outdoors, including in your own home, in restaurants or the park.

The decision for a maximum of 10 others per week, ensures that social contacts remain limited, while still allowing people to see others, according to Wilmès.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium: From 10 May, every family may receive a maximum of four people - always the same - at home. date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Antwerp, Belgium, July 26th.
Antwerp Province’s crisis cell decided on Saturday to limit each individual to a contact bubble of no more than 10 persons for the next four weeks. Each resident will be “invited” to keep a written record of the name, address and telephone numbers of these persons, the crisis cell said.

As has been the case in the city of Antwerp since Saturday, public gatherings of more than 10 persons are banned throughout the province. The crisis cell, which met on Saturday, is also asking residents to practice social distancing within their contact groups and to postpone private parties.

Anyone above the age of 12 needs to wear a face mask in all “highly frequented public places.”

description:
On 3 June, Belgium announced that from the 8th of June group meetings are limited to a maximum of 10 people, including children. This applies to all meetings, regardless of whether they take place at home or away from home.

UPDATE: From 29 July social bubble of a household has to be reduced to 5 persons (under 12 years old children not included). These 5 persons need to be the same during the following month.

Family gatherings are limited to 10 persons maximum (under 12 years old children not included).

These measures stay in force at least until the end of August. UPDATE: The original policy was set to limit group meetings to 10 people, it has been reduced to 5 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
West-Vlaanderen, Belgium, 30 July 2020. 
Several towns in the province of West-Vlaanderen have taken measures that are stricter than the federal norm. One of the measures requires the wearing of a mouth mask on the public domain and all publicly accessible places. Furthermore, wearing a face mask will be mandatory at all events, in queues, public infrastructures and buildings, public spaces and recycling parks.

Those who exercise do not have to wear a mouth mask. All sports competitions may only take place without an audience, both indoors and outdoors. Furthermore, events with more than 100 attendees are now prohibited, regardless of whether they take place indoors or outdoors.

The events must be approved in advance by the mayor and those attending an event must register and wear a mask. Occasional markets, such as flea markets, are also banned.

The municipalities, in collaboration with W13, are also continuing to consult with the Flemish government about local contact tracing. They want to start that up as soon as possible. The measures will go into effect throughout the Midwest zone starting July 30.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Single Recreational or commercial event allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On Wednesday 23 September 2020, Belgium's National Security Council decided to abolish the concept of the “bubble of five” to limit people’s social contacts. Every person – not household – is now allowed to have five close contacts, and see everyone they want, if they keep their distance.

On top of that, professionally organised gatherings no longer have a maximum number of guests, the mandatory quarantine period has been shortened, people returning from orange zones will no longer be asked to get tested, and face masks rules will be relaxed from October.

description:
Belgium's Security Council introduced long-term coronavirus strategy to curb the spread of the coronavirus on 23 September 2020. 

Instead of the social bubble, there will be a "reference number" that will vary between 1 and 5, depending on the health situation. At the moment, experts recommend a maximum of 5 close contacts per person per month.

Close contacts with people who are not a member of your household, for more than 15 minutes and without a distance of 1.5 m and without a face mask should be limited as much as possible. 

Apart from those close contacts, people can see as many people as they want, as long as they keep their distance and respect the
hygiene rules. However, meeting more than 10 people at a time is still not allowed.

description:
Between July 29, 2020, and August 31, 2020, Belgian Minister of Security and the Interior enacted a restrictions of mass gatherings policy stating that the competent municipal authorities may authorize small festivals and markets, with the exception of annual markets, flea markets, Christmas markets and winter villages. The markets should have a 1.5m distancing, a maximum capacity of 200 persons, and without possibility of offering food and beverages on site.

UPDATE: The Belgian Minister of Security and the Interior enacted restrictions of mass gatherings on shopping streets, markets, including flea markets and fair grounds on 25 September 2020 until 31 October 2020. 

The merchants, fair grounds and their staff are requiredm to cover their mouth and nose with a mask, any other alternative cloth or, when this is not possible for medical reasons, with a face shield;

The competent communal authorities shall make available the products necessary for the hygiene of the hands, at the entrances and exits of the market or funfair; UPDATE: The original restriction of shopping streets, markets, including flea markets and fair grounds was set to 31 August 2020, it has been extended to 31 October 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Belgian government has set rules to stop the spread of coronavirus on 30 September 2020:
- You can meet in a group of maximum 10 people. Children under 12 years old should not be counted among these 10 people.
- You may have close contact with a maximum of 5 and the same people. It is not necessary to keep a distance of 1.5 meters. Children under 12 years old should not be counted among these 5 people.
- You can meet with whoever you want. Always keep a distance of 1.5 metres or wear a mouth mask.

These rules are valid until and including 8 October 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 3 June, Belgium announced that from the 8th of June group meetings are limited to a maximum of 10 people, including children. This applies to all meetings, regardless of whether they take place at home or away from home.

Belgian authorities announced that beginning Friday, October 9, some coronavirus disease (COVID-19)-restrictions will be tightened due to a rise in reported cases in recent days.

From Friday, the number of people that individuals are allowed to have close contact with outside of their household has been lowered to three. Additionally, no more than four people should be invited inside a home or gather outside. UPDATE: The original policy limited group meetings to a maximum of 10 people from June 3rd. From October 9th, it has been lowered to three people.

description:
Belgium: October 16th, 2020: The Consultative Committee has decided to move the entire country into alert level 4 on October 19th, 2020 until November 19th, 2020 (one month). Restrictions include: 

-Cuddle contacts (close contacts) limited to one person. 
- Private gatherings limited to the same 4 people every two-week window. - Outdoor gatherings limited to 4 people. 
- Receptions and banquets catered for by a professional caterer/catering company are forbidden.
- Professional sports competitions attendance will be halved from 400 to 200 spectators, canteens and drinking establishments must be closed.

description:
Wallonia, Belgium, 24 October 2020. 

Belgium’s French-speaking Walloon region has announced that it will be tightening the national curfew measures in efforts to clamp down on soaring coronavirus infections.

From Saturday until 19 November all of Wallonia will be required to respect a curfew between 10:00 PM and 6:00 AM, Walloon Minister-President Elio Di Rupo announced on Friday evening.

In addition to the curfew, only two people will be allowed to shop together, not accounting for children.

description:
It was announced on the 8th of October, 2020 that in Belgium gatherings of more than 4 people above 12 years old are prohibited, except for certain events and activities.

UPDATE: The Minister of the Interior has announced on 1st November, 2020 that gatherings of more than four persons, children until the age of 12 years excluded, are only authorized under certain conditions. Each household is authorized to accommodate at home or in a maximum tourist accommodation the same sustainable close contact per household member at once in a period of 6 weeks.

The following rules must be respected:
- social distancing of 1.5 metres
- masks and other means of personal protection are at all times strongly recommended
- the activity must be organized in such a way as to avoid gatherings
- provision with the products necessary for the hygiene of hands; UPDATE: The original policy of mass gatherings was extended from 8th October 2020 to 1st November 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: October 30th, 2020: As of November 2nd, 2020, the Consultative Committee put in place new mass gathering restrictions:

-Marriages can only take place with the spouses, witnesses, and civil registrars
-Funerals are limited to 15 attendees. No meal or reception afterwards is allowed
-Prayer houses can remain open, but gatherings are limited to 4 people with masks and social distancing. No services to be held.
-Outdoor mass gatherings limited to 4 people with masks and social distancing rules (1.5-meter distancing)

This policy will be in place until the 13th of December when the Consultative Committee will reassess.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee has published a new outdoor gathering plan. As of March 8th, 2021, 10 people can meet outside together, but a distance of 1.5 meters must still be kept. 
A priority is being given to children and young people. Organised outdoor gatherings (including sports) for children 13 and under is limited to 10 people outside and 25 inside. For young people, aged 19 and younger, a limit of 10 people is in place for organised outdoor gatherings. Audiences for organised outdoor gatherings of children and youth is limited to 1 per participant.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium: As of March 8th, 2021, the Consultative Committee has decided that funerals and burials can have up to 50 people and a maximum of 1 person per 10 square meters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Consultative Committee of Belgium decides on an outdoor plan: from 8 March, more people can meet outside.

More people outside

As from 8 March, groups of 10 people can meet outside. It remains important to keep a distance of 1.5 metres.
Funerals

 From 8 March onwards, it will be possible to attend a funeral inside with a maximum of 50 people and a maximum of 1 person per 10 square metres.

Priority for young people and education

From 8 March, organised outdoor activities (sports and others) are allowed:  for children (under the age of 13) with a maximum of 10 indoors or 25 outdoors; for young people (under the age of 19) with a maximum of 10 outdoors.
The audience at sports training sessions is limited to one person per child.

Outdoor plan

As far as the epidemiological situation allows, and depending on the pressure on hospitals and the progress of the vaccination campaign, an outdoor plan will be implemented from April onwards which will allow for the following activities to be carried out:

Organised outdoor activities for everyone (from sports and other associations, including sports training): a maximum of 10 people. The audience at sports training sessions will be limited to one individual per person under the age of 19;
Culture, events and religious services: a maximum of 50 people, provided that social distancing rules are respected and face masks are worn;
Amusement parks;
Primary and secondary education: after the Easter holidays, every day in the classroom.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Between June 9, 2020, and May 2, 2023, Belgium enacted a restrictions of mass gatherings policy stating that events (cultural, sports, shows…) can start up again. 
Indoors: up to 200 people or 75% of the room capacity, seated, with face masks, and at a safe distance from each other. 
Outdoors: up to 400 people, with face masks and at a safe distance from each other. 
Non-professional sports: up to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors (except for contact sports).
Ceremonies, weddings, and funerals: up to 100 people indoors and 200 people outdoors allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: In step 2 of the four-step plan starting the 1st of July, events like cultural performances, shows and sports competitions can take place indoors with up to 2000 people or 80% of the room capacity present. They must be seated, with face masks and at a safe distance from each other. Outdoors up to 2500 people are allowed. Face masks and at a safe distance from each other are required. However, non-professional sports can occur without restrictions. 
Youth activities, camps, and social activities can have up to 100 people, with an overnight stay permitted. Pre-testing is highly recommended.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium: As per the summer four-step plan, the third step will begin on July 30th, 2021. For events like cultural performances, shows, and sports competitions can they can take place indoors with up to 3,000 people or 100% of the room capacity. Face masks and at a safe distance from each other are required. Events can be held outdoors with up to 5,000 people. description:
The Consultative Committee of Belgium has decided to tighten controls on events from July 19. 

The Covid Safe Ticket can be used for events with 1,500 people or more and is available for people who are fully vaccinated (i.e. two weeks after the final dose), have a recovery certificate or a recent negative test result.

From 13 August, the Covid Safe Ticket will only apply to outdoor events for 1,500 people or more. 

From 1 September, indoor events will also be eligible. When using the Covid Safe Ticket, rules concerning face masks, social distancing and CIRM/CERM restrictions are no longer applicable. However, there must be a plan for crowd control management, sanitary precautions must be followed and adequate ventilation (with an indoor CO2 meter) must be provided.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Outdoor events gathering up to 400 people can also be organized without the need for a mask or safe distancing. Larger events can still be organized, however, these requires the Covid Safe Ticket, which indicates proof of full vaccination, a recent negative test result or the presence of antibodies following a recent coronavirus infection.

description:
Belgium: [December 3, 2021] Today, the Consultative Committee has discussed the epidemiological situation in our country. To reduce the pressure on our health system, it has been decided to limit indoor activities, to bring forward the Christmas holidays for pre-school and primary school education to 20 December and to switch to hybrid education in secondary schools. People are also urged to limit social contacts indoors as much as possible.
All indoor activities and gatherings are prohibited for the time being, including organised activities, but with the exception of: sports,
private gatherings organised at home or in a small tourist accommodation,
weddings and funerals.
Indoor sports competitions must be organised without an audience. Minor participants may be accompanied by two adults.
These measures will take effect on Saturday 4 December 2021.

description:
Belgium: In step 2 of the four-step plan starting the 1st of July, events like cultural performances, shows and sports competitions can take place indoors with up to 2000 people or 80% of the room capacity present. They must be seated, with face masks and at a safe distance from each other. Outdoors up to 2500 people are allowed. Face masks and at a safe distance from each other are required. However, non-professional sports can occur without restrictions. 
Youth activities, camps, and social activities can have up to 100 people, with an overnight stay permitted. Pre-testing is highly recommended. UPDATE: On January 28, 2022, the Belgian government announced that the number of people participating in organized group activities such as youth activities, associations, and amateur sports would be changed from 100 to 80 people indoors and 200 people outdoors.

description:
Belgium On 8th of March 2022. 
Events
Indoors - Practically no measures. No use of a Covid Safe Ticket (CST). Only use of CO2 meter is mandatory.
Outdoors - Practically no measures. For closed tents or covered terraces, the indoor air standards apply.
Hospitality industry: Bars, restaurants
Indoors - Virtually no measures: no closing time, no CST, no facemasks (including for staff in the hospitality sector). Use of CO2 meter obligatory.
Outdoors - Also, virtually no measures. For closed tents or covered terraces, the indoor air standards apply.
Leisure
Indoors - Practically no measures apply. Extra attention should be paid to good ventilation.
Outdoors - No measures apply.

description:
On Tuesday 17 March, the National Security Council, which has been expanded to include the Ministers-President, decided to take additional measures. On the one hand, these measures are based on the evolution of the spread of Covid-19 in Belgium.
Companies - regardless of size - are obliged to organize teleworking for every function where this is possible, without exception.
For those for whom this organization is not possible, social distancing will be strictly respected. This rule applies to both the performance of the work and the transport organized by the employer. If it is impossible for companies to meet these obligations, they must close their doors.
If the authorities establish that the social distancing measures are not being complied with, the company will in the first instance be fined a heavy one; in case of non-compliance after the sanction, the company will have to close.

The measures set out below will enter into force at noon on Wednesday 18 March and shall be maintained until 5 April. The situation will continue to be assessed on a daily basis and further changes may be made as the situation evolves.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The National Security Council of Belgium enforced new measures on social distancing for companies starting from 18 March 2020.

Companies - regardless of their size - are obliged to organise teleworking for any function where this is possible, without exception.

For those for whom this organization is not possible, social distancing will be strictly respected. This rule applies both to the exercise of the work and to transport organised by the employer. If it is impossible for companies to meet these obligations, they must close their doors.

If the authorities find that the social distancing measures are not being observed, the company will initially be subject to a heavy fine; In case of non-compliance after the sanction, the company will have to close.

These provisions do not apply to the critical sectors and essential services. However, they will have to ensure that the rules on social distancing are observed as far as possible.

These measures will be maintained until 5 April 2020.

description:
In Belgium, all prison visits were suspended between 13 March, 2020 and 25 May, 2020 to protect both inmates and staff.

UPDATE: In Belgium, the Federal Minister of Justice announced a series of measures on 21 March to protect prison staff and prisoners from COVID-19. No visits have been allowed since 13 March. To compensate for this, detainees receive 20 euros extra phone credit. Measures were also taken on the modalities of execution of sentences granted to detainees, namely early release, penitentiary leave and limited detention. In addition, for all interventions staff must wear a mouth mask. Work studios, however, remain open.
 
The Central Council of Penitentiary Surveillance (CCPS) called on the federal Government to urgently strengthen health and humanitarian measures in prisons on 30 March. It noted that in the overcrowded prisons, often with a lack of hygiene, it is impossible to adequately implement prevention and care measures. It therefore recommended to reduce the prison population to the maximum capacity of each facility. The CCPS also proposed several measures to improve the situation 
of detainees, such as making phone calls free of charge, and ensuring sufficient hygiene products and access to running water. UPDATE: The original policy suspended all prison visits from 13th of March 2020. The federal Government urgently strengthened health and humanitarian measures in prisons on 30 March.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Belgium, the Federal Government decided on 15 April,2020 to allow one visitor at a time in institutions for persons with disabilities and care homes for the elderly. Mass testing in care homes has also been announced by the Belgian government. This is flagged as a T, since Flanders and the Walloon region only followed suit with allowing visitors later in the month.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: It was announced 15th of April, 2020 that in Belgium residents of residential facilities – for example, nursing homes, care homes and facilities for the disabled – to be visited by a designated relative or close friend, provided this person has shown no symptoms of the disease for two weeks. This designated individual must always be the same person. The residential facilities will be responsible for organising visits. These rules will also apply to people who live alone and who are unable to leave their home.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
15th of April: Belgium encourages citizens to work from home.
The instructions are as follows:
Keep working, but work from home as much as possible. Postpone meetings or organise them online. When at work, keep a distance from each other and follow the hygiene prescriptions. If possible, change working hours so that less people are at work at the same time.

This advice is set to last until May 3rd. UPDATE: Belgium has encouraged citizens to work from home. This policy has been extended to May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: April 15th: Belgium places a ban on all gatherings, until May 3rd. UPDATE: The original ban on gatherings was set to last until April 5th, it has been extended to May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From April 21st, all care centre staff in contact with residents will have to wear a surgical mask if there is sufficient supply. However, this does not apply to administrative staff who have no contact with the residents.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

This becomes effective on April 22, 2020.

description:
Brussels-Capital, Belgium, April 23 2020.

In Brussels-Capital Region, the Government reached an agreement on the conditions of visits in care homes for the elderly on 23 April. The spokesperson of the Brussels Minister of Health and Wellbeing announced in the press, however, that although the new rules are in place, visits will only be possible once everyone has been tested, and the residential care centre in question has all the means to manage the visit. Weekly, only one regular visitor per resident will be admitted, and the duration of the visit may be limited by the rest home. Visitors must adhere to strict hygiene measures, including compulsory wearing of a mask and keeping a distance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Walloon, Belgium, April 27 2020.
In the Walloon Region, the Walloon Minister for Employment, Social Action, Health and Equal Opportunities stated that care homes would not allow visitors until testing is completed.

On 27 April, the Walloon Government subsequently announced the conditions for visits in the care  homes for elderly persons. The visitor will have to bring his or her own surgical mask, the distance rules must be observed and it will be strictly forbidden to hand objects directly to residents. In any case, children under 12 years of age will not be allowed to enter a care home.79 The Walloon Health Minister confirmed in the media that all staff and residents of the Walloon care homes for elderly will have been tested by 3 May, which will then open up the possibility of visits under strict conditions and if the organisation and sanitary equipment allow it.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On the basis of recommendations from the Group of Experts in charge of the Exit Strategy (GEES), the National Security Council met today, Friday 24 April, in the Egmont Palace to determine the exit strategy from the corona crisis. Covering the mouth and nose is important when scaling down the measures. This can be done using a so-called comfort mask or an alternative means of protection such as a scarf or a bandana. This is:

recommended in public places
mandatory on public transport for users aged 12 years and over. This measure will enter into force on 4 May. A mask alone does not provide adequate protection, it should be considered within the wider use of mouth masks, hygiene measures and physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Unspecified outdoor spaces
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Belgium, 4 May 2020. 

Belgium will enter the first phase of phasing out on May 4. The core with ministers-presidents of the regions, communities and the experts of the GEES announced that on May 4, Belgium will enter phase 1A, in concrete terms, this means:
- The resumption of economic activity between professionals and companies, 
- The reopening of fabric and yarn shops,
- Teleworking remains the norm. Safe distances at work must be respected. However, compensatory measures are permitted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, Wallonia, 4 May 2020. 
In its deconfinement strategy, the Walloon government has decided that technical inspection stations can once again offer their services, since Monday 4 May, to all inspection services and for all vehicles.

This reopening is accompanied by "strict health measures", as announced by the Walloon authorities in a press release:
- these checks will only be carried out by appointment;
- only one person is allowed per vehicle.
- wearing a mask is mandatory for all customers.
- all customers must strictly respect the instructions communicated at the station, the ground markings and the safety distances of a minimum of 1.5 meters with staff and other customers.
- inspectors will be equipped with masks and gloves.
- payments will be made only electronically.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Between May 4, 2020, and June 30, 2020, Belgian Minister of Security and the Interior enacted a social distancing policy stating that all individuals aged 12 or over are mandated to wear a face mask or cover their nose and mouth in all public transport, at stops and within transit establishments.

description:
The Belgian rail services will return to “near-normal levels” from 4 May. 

A maximum number of available carriages will be used to try and ensure social distancing. Mouth masks will be mandatory at stations, on platforms and inside trains. Passengers will be requested to observe the rule on social distancing. This means that if it can possible be avoided passengers should not sit next to each other on board trains.

Train guards will be able to call the police if passengers fail to respect the rules on social distancing and mouth masks.

Trains will continue to be disinfected at regular intervals. The station too will be cleaned regularly with special attention being paid to the hygiene of surfaces often touched by passengers (and staff) such as door handles, tables, ticket machines.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The prime minister of Belgium advised people to travel on their own (on foot, bicycle, car), and to leave places for those who need it to work on conference on April 24. 

There is a general duty to wear masks in public transportation (for example on TEC "Since Monday, May 4, the wearing of a mask is compulsory for all travellers over the age of 12"), there are restrictions on the number of passengers per vehicle. Due to school closures and lower demand the transportation companies reduced their offerings: "the buses will continue to run on the basis of the timetables established for the school holiday periods. This measure ... will apply until the gradual opening of schools scheduled for May 18."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From May 11th, driving instructors are allowed to resume teaching, and from May 18th, all tests, practical and theoretical, in the AM, A, C, and D categories will be possible again. From May 25th, practical tests for the B, BE, and G categories will be permitted again. However, certain measures will become mandatory such as wearing a face mask in the car during lessons or the practical exams. Centers will also disinfect the car each time. People who are feeling ill are recommended to make another appointment.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description:
Belgium, 11 May 2020.

The mayors of Belgium's coastal municipalities will follow the guidelines of the National Security Council for reopening the beaches, despite some earlier grievances.

Additionally, a single uniform framework will be provided in which coastal municipalities can take measures tailored to their own needs, concerning traffic circulation for cars as well as people, a beach plan with a focus on access to the beach, supervised bathing areas from 27 June, and a circulation and terrace plan.

Each municipality will be allowed to implement these plans based on the number of visitors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Beaches
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Belgium, May 9 2020. 
The Brussels public transport company MIVB is to increase the number of buses, trams and underground trains in operation on its network. As on the services operated by other public transport providers such as De Lijn and Belgian Railways (NMBS) everyone over the age of 12 that uses an MIVB bus, tram or metro will be obliged to wear a mouth mask. Passengers are also requested to try and maintain social distancing whenever possible and to only travel if they really need to. MIVB advised passengers to try and avoid travel during peak times if they can.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Flanders, Belgium - On May 15th, 2020 Flemish Minister of Mobility and Public Works has put together a "toolbox for sustainable mobility" and launched a campaign called #blijvenfietsen ('keep cycling'). The Minister also wants to widen cycling and walking paths and pedestrian crossings to ensure social distancing, and add signs encouraging people to use their elbows rather than their hands when pushing buttons on traffic lights.

description:
The National Security Council (NSC), extended with the ministers-president had a meeting today, Wednesday 13 May. On the basis of the GEES experts' report, the NSC decided to start phase 2 of the phase-out plan as from 18 May. A second aspect in this phase is culture. The NSC has decided that museums and cultural sights - historic buildings and monuments, castles, citadels - can be reopened as from 18 May, provided they set up an online or telephone ticketing system and take the necessary measures to avoid drawing crowds. Libraries can remain open, under the same conditions as now.
Natural tourist sites, such as zoos, will also be allowed to reopen, provided that they introduce an online or telephone ticketing system to restrict public access, draw up a circulation plan and that cafeterias and restaurants remain closed, as well as any rides and playgrounds.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Tourist Sites
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from the 18th of May, 2020 in Belgium in beauty institutes, non-medical pedicure institutes, manicure salons, hairdressing salons, barbers and tattoo and piercing studios, the following modalities apply to clients' reception: customers can only come in by appointment in the strictly necessary duration of the service, waiting rooms and toilets can not be used for customers, workstations must be separated by a distance of at least 1.5 meters; and it is forbidden to offer food or drinks. Any person from the age of 12 is held to cover his mouth and nose by means of a mask or any other alternative in fabric.

description:
Belgium, 27 May 2020.

The Minister of Security and the Interior has announced that playgrounds can be visited, and should be reserved for children up to 12 years old, accommodating a maximum of 20 children at a time, while adults accompanying children respect the rules of social distancing, in particular maintaining a distance of 1.5 meters between each person.

This Order comes into force on May 27, 2020.

description:
In Belgium performances with an audience - including cinemas - can be resumed from 1 July, but only subject to specific rules regarding crowd management, such as respecting the safety distance in the audience and a maximum of 200 attendees.
Activities should be organised in such a way as to avoid gatherings of too many people, e.g. outside the venue.  When people take part in cultural and leisure activities, wearing a mask is recommended at all times.

description: Starting from the 8th of June, 2020 In Belgium the safety distance remains valid, except for people within the same family, for children under the age of 12 with each other and for people with closer contact, i.e. the expanded bubble. Anyone who cannot respect the safety distance must wear a face mask.  ( Because of the option for each family to define an "expanded bubble" (10 people that can change weekly), H6=2G is kept as masks must be worn in specific public spaces (e.g. public transportation) but not in all public places with people present.

description:
From 8th of June, 2020 in Belgium the rules regarding safety distance continue to apply, except for people within the same family, for children under the age of 12 and for people with whom there is closer contact, i.e. the extended bubble. Those who cannot respect the safety distance have to wear a mouth mask.
It is possible to have closer contact with 10 different people every week, in addition to the family members (= extended personal bubble). This is an individual right. These 10 people can change from one week to the next.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Face masks in all busy places, registering at restaurants or pubs, extra travel documents: corona measures extended from July 25, 2020.
Night shops are to close earlier, pubs and restaurants will have to register all customers and keep details for two weeks, and face masks will become mandatory in busy places like markets or shopping streets across the country: Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès of Belgium has announced stricter "Restriction and Regulation of Businesses" policy after a new meeting of the National Security Council with federal and regional ministers and health experts, considering the worsening Covid statistics. Unless local authorities have stated otherwise, the new measures will apply as of Saturday.

description: Starting from the 1st of September, 2020 in Belgium individuals above 12 years old with a disability or medical condition,  upon showing a valid medical certificate, are not required to wear a mask in the following establishments: shops and shopping centers; conference rooms; cinemas; theaters, concert halls or conference halls; places of worship; libraries; museums; casinos and automatic gaming halls; the shopping streets; any public buildings; the markets; the establishments and places where Horeca activities are allowed, both customers and staff, except while they eat, drink or sit at table.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 23rd September the NSC introduced Phase 3 of the coronavirus strategy - Risk Management. Face masks must still be worn when safety distances cannot be guaranteed. However, as of 1 October wearing face masks will no longer be mandatory outdoors, except in very busy areas where safety distance cannot be maintained (as determined by local authorities) and in specific indoor areas such as on public transport, in shops, or in cinemas, regardless of how busy they are.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Belgium, 23 September: As far as wearing the mouth mask is concerned, this remains mandatory when the safety distance cannot be guaranteed. However, as it is useless to make it mandatory anywhere, anytime, wearing a face mask will no longer be mandatory outdoors from October 1, except in high-traffic areas where the safety distance cannot be respected (determined by the local authorities) and in specific covered areas. Places, such as on public transport, in shops or cinemas and regardless of the number of people (for a complete list, consult the ministerial order).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgium tightened coronavirus restrictions just days after relaxing rules on masks on Oct. 7, 2020.  After a surge in new cases Belgians, especially, older people have to wear masks, limit the close contact up to 3 people, and practice social distancing.

description: Belgium: Anyone from the age of 12 is obliged to cover his mouth and nose with a mask or other alternative fabric from the entrance to the airport, the train station, on the dock or a bus stop , on the bus, the subway, the tram, the train or any other means of transport organized by a public authority. When the port of a mask or a fabric alternative is not possible for medical reasons, a facial screen can be used.

description: Belgium: Anyone from the age of 12 is obliged to cover the mouth and nose with a mask or other alternative fabric in the following places: shops and shopping centers; cinemas; theatre, concert or conference rooms; places of worship; museums; libraries; casinos and automatic gaming rooms; trade fairs, including salons; the shopping streets, the markets, and any private or public place with high attendance. In restaurants, bars and cafes, a mask should be worn by both customers and staff, except while they eat, drink or sit at the table.

description: From October 18th, 2020 until November 19th, 2020, Belgium allows institutions of higher education and social advancement education to continue their lessons and activities in accordance with the "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy from directives of the Communities and the additional measures provided by the federal government. Ministry of Education set conditions for the organization of lessons and schools such as the number of days of attendance at schools, mask-wearing, the presence of third parties, and extracurricular activities.

description: From 23rd of October, 2020 in Belgium the following institutions may remain open: all types of accommodation, including their restaurant but excluding their bar, and only for clients who stay there; community kitchens for residential, school, life and work communities; collective facilities for homeless people; and catering establishments and beverage rates in airport transit areas. These establishments should follow all distancing guidelines, with a maximum of 4 people per table authorized and closed bar service.

description: Belgium - On October 23rd, 2020, Consultative Committee announced the "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy, which raised the coronavirus rules for higher education to alert level 4 until November 19th, 2020. The occupancy rate in higher education is reduced to a maximum of 20% with compulsory face masks, except for practical lessons where this is impossible. The rule does not apply to first-year students.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium, 23 October 2020. 
The Consultative Committee has raised the coronavirus rules for sports, cultural events and (higher) education to alert level 4.

Public transport: all authorities ensure, within their competence, that the capacity of public transport during peak hours is limited to prevent overcrowding.

Given the particular urgency of the situation, the rules will enter into force immediately from the moment of publication on Friday 23 October 2020. The rules shall be applicable until 19 November 2020, with a mid-term review after two weeks.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Starting from 24th of October, 2020 in Wallonia, Belgium in nursing homes, only one visitor will be allowed, and a mask must be worn at all times. This person can change every 15 days, and must be organised in a dedicated space, not a room. Exceptions can only be made in end of life situations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: Excemption: Individuals who are older than 12 years old, at any organized events, including representations, funerals, weddings, any public buildings or public markets, but who have medical conditions or disabilities, are exempt from wearing a mask, in Liege, Belgium.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Between October 25, 2020, and November 19, 2020, Belgium's Governor of the province of Liège enacted a social distancing policy stating that wearing a mask is obligatory an hour before and after the entry and exit, or in proximity of any entrance, of education establishments including primary, secondary, and higher education schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Between October 25, 2020, and November 19, 2020, Belgian Governor of the province of Liège enacted a social distancing policy stating that when it is impossible to maintain a 1.5m distance, all individuals older than 12 years old are obliged to wear a mask or any other tissue alternative at any organized events, including representations, funerals, weddings, and any public buildings.

description:
On October 26, 2020, the Belgian Government announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy effective until November 2, 2020. 
Flemish-speaking region: Safety measures have been tightened in all Flemish-speaking schools. Face masks are made compulsory for pupils older than 12 in the schoolyard unless they can keep a distance. Secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively. In universities, 20 percent of students will be allowed to attend on-site, while the rest must follow classes remotely. Half of the first-year students can attend on-site. However, almost all higher education institutions have switched to digital classes, even though they are not obliged to do so by the Flemish government. French-speaking region: Classes in secondary schools will be done virtually from October 28, 2020,; no pupils will be allowed on site. All university courses are now virtual, including for first-year students. There will no longer be any on-site presence until November 19, 2020. In Flanders, safety measures have been tightened; secondary schools can provide distance learning for second and third grades (students from 14 to 18 years old) if necessary, on the condition that all pupils can be reached effectively.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Between October 26, 2020, and November 19, 2020, Belgian Minister-President of the Brussels-Capital Region enacted a social distancing policy stating that wearing a mask is not compulsory when playing a sport, performing intensive physical work on public roads and for people with a disability that does not allow them to wear a mask or face shield. Additionally, wearing a mask is not compulsory for cyclists and scooter users when they are traveling on public roads.

description:
Belgium, 28 October 2020.

The Minister of the Interior of Belgium has announced emergency measures to limit the spread of the COVID-19 on 28 October 2020. 

Companies and associations offering goods or services to consumers should inform customers and staff members of the measures and provide appropriate training for workers. They also should guarantee a distance of 1.5 meters between each person or one customer per 10 m2, where clients can enter for a maximum period of 30 minutes or as long as is customary in the event of an appointment.

If the area accessible to customers is less than 20 m2, it is allowed to accommodate two guests, provided that a distance of 1.5 meters is guaranteed between each person;

Masks and other means of personal protection are in all times highly recommended. 

The companies and enterprises should provide staff and customers with the products necessary for the hygiene of hands. They are required to disinfect regularly the establishment and the equipment used and ensure good ventilation. 

Customers and staff can report possible coronavirus contamination COVID-19 to facilitate contact tracing;
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Belgium, December 18th. 

The Consultative Committee has decided that it is not possible to relax any of the measures in force. There will be additional measures and stricter controls of the existing rules will be put in place.

- Cities and municipalities are asked to continue and, if necessary, intensify their efforts against unauthorised gatherings, shopping for pleasure and cross-border shopping.

- Shopping must be done individually and may only last up to 30 minutes.

- Trade unions and employers are asked to propose stricter measures, in particular to avoid high-risk situations.

- The Committees for Protection and Prevention at Work will assist in monitoring compliance with sanitary measures and social distancing rules.

description:
In Belgium from 5 March, 2021, you are allowed to have close contact with a maximum of 1 person (always the same person). Keeping 1.5 meters distance is not necessary in that case.
Are you inviting someone to your home? Each family member is entitled to close contact with 1 person. Families can only invite 1 person to their home at any one time, with whom they have close contact.
Do you live on your own? You are allowed to invite your close contact and one extra person to your home. These people cannot be in your house at the same time.
You can meet up outside in groups of maximum 4 people. You must keep a distance of 1.5 meters. Children up to the age of 12 do not need to be taken into account.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 19, 2021, the Belgian Government announced a "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy effective in the period between March 24, 2021, and March 27, 2021:
- The possibility for 2nd-level secondary school pupils to take full-time face-to-face lessons again, initially scheduled for March 29, 2021, has been postponed until the start of the school year following the Easter holidays.  
- Wearing a mask becomes compulsory for all 5th and 6th-year primary pupils, at the latest from Wednesday, March 24, 2021.  
- Full-time face-to-face teaching in secondary education will only be possible after the Easter holidays on April 19, 2021    
- 100% face-to-face teaching must be accompanied by regular tests of teachers and, in a second phase, of pupils.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium: The Consultative Committee is allowing classes to resume April 19th for nursery education, primary education, special needs secondary education, the first stage of secondary education, and the system of ‘learning and working’ in 100% full-time face-to-face education. However, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary education is 50% face-to-face education. For higher education, only 1 day/week can be physically on campus. 
Exams can be taken in person. Indoor day trips will be permitted. Face masks for those in the fifth and sixth years of primary are still required. Interaction between classes is advised to be as limited as possible.
Depending on the covid situation at the time, 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary can more to 100% face-to-face education May 3rd.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belgium lays out rules to reopen terraces from 8 May.

Belgium's authorities have agreed on the rules and frameworks for the planned relaxations of the coronavirus measures, announced Prime Minister Alexander De Croo.

"The progress of the vaccination campaign allows us to say that, on 8 May the so-called 'outdoor plan' can come into force, meaning the terraces can open," he said.

From 8 May, the terraces of the hospitality sector will be allowed open.

- Up to four customers per table can be served. Exceptions will be made larger for households.
- Terraces can open between 8:00 AM and 10:00 PM.
- There is no maximum number of people allowed per terrace, but tables have to be at 1.5 metres distance from each other.
- People have to be served at their table, and all staff have to wear face masks.
- When moving around, to go to the toilet for example, customers also have to wear a mask.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Regarding restriction & regulation of business in Belgium. These measures are valid until 26 June.

Shops and catering industry

All shops are open.
You are allowed to go shopping with 2 other people. Children up to and including 12 years old should not be taken into account
When you enter the store disinfect your hands first.
Wear a face mask. This is mandatory.
Do you own a shop? Read the guide by the FPS Economy.
Markets are being organized.
You can visit the market in groups of four. Children up to and including 12 years old should not be taken into account. Keep a distance of 1,5 meters from other groups.
You can eat and drink at the market.
Night shops are open until 11:30 PM.
Hairdressers and other non-medical contact professions, such as pedicure and beauty salons, are open.

Bars and restaurants

Cafés and restaurants are open from 5 AM until 11:30 PM.
You are allowed at the table in groups of maximum 4 people or with the people you live with. Children up to and including 12 years old should not be taken into account.
You must remain seated at the table. You do not need to wear a face mask.
If you need to go to the toilet or pay the bill, make sure to wear a face mask.
Do you own a pub or restaurant? Read the guide by the FPS Economy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Between June 9, 2021, and July 1, 2021, Belgium enacted a restriction and regulation of businesses policy stating that catering industry will reopen indoors between 8am and 10pm. The maximum number of people per table is 4 or one household per table. A distance of least 1.5 meters must be maintained between tables. Outdoor catering establishments will be able to remain open until 11.30pm instead of 10pm. The table rules will remain the same: 4 people or one household per table and a distance of 1.5 meters between tables. Parties and receptions: up to 50 people indoors.This is the first step in the summer four-step plan.

description: A "Closure and Regulation of Schools" policy was declared in Belgium on August 11, 2021, which mandates students in schools located in the Wallonia and Flanders regions to wear masks as a preventive measure against the coronavirus. The policy became effective on August 15, 2021. Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19. Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.

Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.

The government of the Flanders region decided on Oct. 27 to make masks obligatory in the last two grades of primary schools after a speedy rise of infections.

Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region.

Also, Wallonian high school students have to wear masks during classes, while primary school students can stay in the classroom without masks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.

Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.

The government of the Flanders region decided on Oct. 27 to make masks obligatory in the last two grades of primary schools after a speedy rise of infections.

Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region.

Also, Wallonian high school students have to wear masks during classes, while primary school students can stay in the classroom without masks. UPDATE: Tuesday, August 17, 2021  Regulations on the wearing of masks in schools have been relaxed in Wallonia, education ministers confirmed on Tuesday.Staff working in educational institutions in Wallonia, will now no longer have to wear masks when moving around the institutions. Pupils will still be required to wear masks outside if social distancing cannot be respected.

type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description:
New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.

Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.

The government of the Flanders region decided on Oct. 27 to make masks obligatory in the last two grades of primary schools after a speedy rise of infections.

Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region.

Also, Wallonian high school students have to wear masks during classes, while primary school students can stay in the classroom without masks. UPDATE: in Wallonia face masks in the classroom are a thing of the past: when students sit down or stand still in class they can take off their masks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Belgium: BRUSSELS (Reuters) - Belgian schools will reopen on Sept. 1 when the academic year starts, with children above 12 years old and teachers required to wear masks during the coronavirus pandemic, Prime Minister Sophie Wilmes said on Thursday. Date: 08.20.2020 UPDATE: Belgium: 23.09.2021  From 1 October, the rules for schools in the Brussels-Capital Region will remain the same. in Francophone secondary schools in Brussels (and Wallonia), face masks in the classroom are a thing of the past: when students sit down or stand still in class they can take off their masks.

description:
Covid emergency: CST in Flanders, masks and homeworking are back on Nov 1, 2022.
Belgium is introducing new measures to combat the rise in coronavirus cases. Starting 1 November the Covid Safe Ticket (CST) will be required in hospitality and gyms in Flanders.  Face coverings become obligatory in public indoor spaces across the nation, while homeworking is once again highly recommended.

description:
Belgium requires students in more regions to wear masks in 
classes. New rules entered into force on Monday in Belgium that oblige students to wear facial masks in schools of Wallonia and Flanders regions as part of measures against the coronavirus.
Students of 5th and 6th grades in Flemish primary schools, as well as secondary school students in Wallonia, must wear facial masks during classes as of Monday after regional authorities imposed in October new rules to stem the spread of COVID-19.Flemish secondary schoolers can still attend the classes without covering their noses and mouths because the vaccination rate for the age group of 12-18 is high in the region. 
Date: 11.08.2021
 UPDATE: 27.10.2021 Stricter rules are being implemented across a variety of sectors in Belgium to curb the rising number of infections and limit the damage as a result of this, including in schools across the country. Flemish speaking schools: Within the classroom, pupils will be given a fixed seat, and the current face mask rules, making them mandatory for pupils in the fifth and sixth grades of primary schools, will remain in place. French speaking schools: Meanwhile, the face mask obligation remains the same, meaning this will not be mandatory for nursery and primary school pupils. In secondary schools, students have to wear face masks, even when seated.

description:
Belgium: From 6 December 2021: 
* Mandatory CO2 meters in every classroom and in rooms where many people congregate.
* The imposition of a new protocol on year groups to close as soon as there are two infected cases.
* Mandatory face masks from the age of six.
* Ban on out-of-school activities.
* Parents are recommended to encourage their children to test themselves regularly.

description: In response to the spread of the Omicron variant, indoor venues such as cinemas, theaters, concert halls, and conferences will have to close on December 26th. This announcement made on December 22nd will also include public access to stadiums, sporting events, and outdoor venues under tents. However, outdoor Christmas markets are allowed to stay open with a restriction on capacity. While museums, libraries, and sports facilities will be allowed to remain open, amusement parks are required to be closed by the 26th. Shopping will be allowed but only in pairs, excluding children.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

 UPDATE: Flemish: Masks should also be lifted in secondary school from March, says Education Minister Monday, February 14, 2022. Primary school children will no longer have to wear face masks in class from next week.
Now that the Consultative Committee has decided to lift the obligation to wear a face mask for children under 12 years old from next week, the next step should be doing the same for those up to 18 years old.

description:
On Friday 4 March 2022, the Consultative Committee met to take new measures following the positive evolution of the health situation in Belgium. The Expat Welcome Desk explains it all to you. The wearing of masks (for people over 12 years of age) remains mandatory in public transport, hospitals and nursing homes. 
It is no longer compulsory in the education sector as of Monday 7 March.
It is recommended to keep wearing the mask in indoor spaces (when crowded) and in places where the 1.5 meters distance cannot be maintained.

description: December 15, 2020: With Bulletin N. 317, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health attended a meeting with other European States including Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland. The aim of the meeting was to discuss the vaccination campaign and the need to coordinate efforts for the safe and efficient use of the COVID-19 vaccine. During the meeting, the Ministers agreed to promote the coordination of the vaccination campaign and the rapid sharing of information between national and international authorities. Furthermore, they agreed on a fast sharing of information and experiences in the field of pharmacovigilance. The Ministers also committed to fight disinformation and fake news over the vaccination campaign. Finally, the Health Ministers agreed on the need to ensure a clear and transparent communication to the population about vaccines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Central Commission for the navigation of the Rhine CCNR (Switzerland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium) "has taken exceptional measures in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic to ensure a good performance of Rhine navigation and that the supply chain continues to operate.
The resolution adopted this Monday, 23 March 2020, will come into force immediately. In addition to infrastructure management and the validity of certificates and attestations, this resolution provides for measures ensuring free movement of crew. A crew member certificate of attestation will be provided in the annex to the resolution." " In accordance with the duration of the Governments established duration of the civil emergency, it shall remain in effect until further notice, but not later than September 23, 2020."

description: May 8, 2020: The Government of the Netherlands announced that “the ministers of Home Affairs of Belgium, of Germany, and the Netherlands are working together intensively and continuously to slow down the spread of COVID-19, by keeping in close contact and regularly exchanging critical information, proposals and solutions.” “Bearing in mind the common interest of a controlled exit and recovery, especially in the areas with shared borders, the ministers are determined to come to well-coordinated plans to ensure a successful exit and recovery of both the individual and the combined Member States.”
